content:
Posted: September 5, 2013
												Great adventure/FF-combat hybrid from the amazing people at Double Fine. It is to Final Fantasy (and adventure games) what games like Deathspank are to Diablo: simplified, humorous, and story-driven derivations. Costume Quest may not necessarily be the hardest game out there, but it is thoroughly enoyable all the way through. Especially if you have fond nostalgic memories of trick-or-treating.The free dlc/expansion called "Grubbins on Ice" that comes with it is also fairly good (it is a sequel, so play it after), however I feel much of my personal enjoyment of the original game came from the accurate recreation of what Halloween used to feel like. I still think there is plenty of room for sequels, but I'd personally like to see a return to Halloween in a town as the primary theme next time. Neighborhoods still have a ton of room they could grow in terms of varying atmosphere and style, so I wouldn't say a sequel back in town would feel redundant.Both the original game and the expansion are full of DF-style humor, as well as lots of side tasks to keep you entertained. This is not a massive game, however, and can be 100% completed in less than ~8 hours (much less if you skip all the cutscenes). Still definitely worth the money, as the experience will leave you satisfied and wanting more.Also, as a diehard DF fan there were a few fantastic references (the Psychonauts shop music at the mall, the Stacking dolls in the mountains), not to mention all the pop-culture jokes.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2011
												The premise of this RPG from the makers of cult classic Psychonauts is simple: You are a child whose halloween night is ruined when your twin sibling is abducted by monsters. In order to save them, you must utilize your never-explained ability to transform into whatever thing you are costumed as. Mecha, unicorn, vampire, a big box of french fries.. there's quite a selection to pick from.The combat itself is simple, traditional turn-based RPG fair with minor quick-time elements to get the most out of your attacks (and the least out of the enemy's) clearly intended to be accessible by players of any age, but anyone will enjoy the dramatic visuals and Double Fine productions brand of humor. The game's length is short, enough to occupy a couple days or one extreme halloween marathon. I finished the main content in six hours, and the included expansion in another two and a half.Expect to see the game on sale again next halloween for the pre-sale price of a big bag of candy.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
												This is essentially a casual RPG for kids, but I'm reviewing it anyway as an adult.Costume Quest is a very short turn-based RPG, but the highlight of its features are what it doesn't have. It's devoid of pretty much any interesting game system. The slim turn-based combat system present is similar to the Final Fantasy games, but you'll get more depth out of Final Fantasy games or 99% of their copycats. All of the combat uses Quick Time Events as well, which gets old after the second or third combat encounter. Game balance is simple and a little skewed. The game can be difficult (but hardly) when you only have two party members, and its trivially easy once you have three.The overworld is linear. There's a tiny bit of exploration to be had, but not much. There are roughly four quests in the entire game, each repeated several times for each phase of the game: find a card off a monster (combat encounters), bob for apples (simple mini-game), trick or treat houses (random combat encounters), and find six hiding kids (semi-hidden on overworld).The game crashed a few times, and since there is no manual save feature at any time, I lost 15-20 minutes of progress each time. The game plays the same every time.There are costumes to get, which are your battle suits or "classes". Variation here is only relevant in the costume's "special ability" but the game is so easy that once you have three party members, battle strategy matters little.Graphics meh, sound meh, witty dialogue is OK but not astounding. No voice acting.I don't recommend this game. You can find much better games in all of its genres for cheaper.  If you insist on wanting it, it's worth $2-3 on a sale perhaps. My playtime says 16 hours but that included a long idling session by accident. It's a 5-7 hour game. I'm surprised this game has a sequel. It's popularity seems dependent on the Double Fine brand, which hasn't been the same for me since Spacebase DF and the Broken Age Kickstarter mishandlings.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												Although Halloween have passed this is game that must be played, and would say going to 'trick or treat' would be funny and challenger. So Costume Quest is a Action RPG with a nice concept on it. As you guys already figure it this game takes place on Halloween, where two siblings, Reynold and Wren, will go ask for candies. The player at this point will choose which sibling to play as. One of the siblings will be kidnapped - depend what siblings you choose - and our missions is to find out her he/she is. During our mission, we will make some quest, and personally this was the worst part for me, because the quest are always the same. Costume Quest has 3 levels, the neighborhood, the mall and a carnival, and on all level the quest are the same, go ask for candy, do eat apple game, find some cards, get the costumes, find kids playing hide-and-seek, same thing happens on the DLC despite the level design is different. But if you put that behind your backs the game is really enjoyable, the game's graphics are a cartoonish style - thing that i love - and are well designed and very colorful, Costume Quest is more than colorful, is nice piece of art! The neighborhood and the others locations can make ous dive on feeling, is like we are on Halloween. And since is a Halloween Theme we will have lot of costumes to wear. Now to get the costumes you need to, get three different materials. When we get the costumes, besides changing our appearance we can go through places we didn't can before and will also gives special skills to use in battles. This battles can arise in two different ways, when you are searching for candy's or on street when you find a troll. When such things happens the scenario will completely change and your suit power will be activated, the battle style is a turn-based + quick time events.  When you do three attacks you will have a change to make the special attack, that can be a offensive or defense move. The special attack will be different according to the suit you are wearing. Since this is a RPG make sence we get XP for doing things, well when you complete the quest, defeat the trolls you will get some XP that will raise your level as well your defenses and your attack. Besides, you can buy in-game booster to help raise your attack and defense, although this is not very important because your enemies don't give a strong fight. Although this is a soundless game, contains a decent amount of humor there, some nice jokes and the dialogues between the characters is funny to read too. Costume Quest really grabbed me from the moment i installed, so is totally recommend! ~ 8/10

content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												Just a very boring game. It lack any real depth.  Combat gets stale very very quickly. Story is just mediocre, tried-and-true. Items, a staple in any RPG, for whatever reason is omitted, where Double Fine could have added some 'tongue-in-cheek' elements. The only faint sense of utility or customizations is from the 'Battle Stamps", which are 'added bonuses' like an extra skill or stats, which seemed meaningless other than the counter-strike or stun skill -- the only one which would give me a chance in battle.The costumes did not offer any stat changes other than the obvious battle mechanic changes. Personally, I was expecting the 'knight' to have a more 'tank-like' role in addition to the 'shield' ability like More HP and lower attack. I'm expecting some differences. You can find yourself very easily overwhelmed in a 2v3 battle with no 'usual' / 'crutch' mechanic to swing the battle in your favor like Items or some OP one-time use ability. Instead you are greeted with persistent in battle costumes (which could have been changed like that of FFX-2 dynamic) and 1 every three turns "super-skill" that aligns with the costume chosen. Oh, and the battles consist of you pressing a button to do more dmg or take less damage.I got as far as the mall and just couldnt careless. The story is unique-ish, but the gameplay is just boring and rather... lame.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												Costume Quest is a charming, fun take on the turn based RPG genre. Sort of condensed. Instead of individually swapping weapons, spells, attacks, and actions you choose costumes that change your appearance, battle abilities and attacks, and help solve free roam puzzles with various actions. On top of that you can choose one additional action or buff for each character and swap them as you choose. Instead of finding and swapping party members you can instead choose their costumes. It really is sort of a "My First RPG", which may sound dull to an adult but it works well enough to engage. My one issue with this system is that there wasn't enough difference between the costumes to incentivise change. You are forced to change to solve some puzzles but I would always switch back before a battle. The battle system is turned based and pretty simple with only a few options each turn. This style lends itself to a little repetition but I tended to enjoy them since they typically don't drag on. One twist (Maybe, I don't play a lot of turn based RPGs) is that to land more powerful attacks you have to complete a QTE. There are several variations but each attack only has one. Things like press at a certain time, wiggle a stick, or repeatedly tap a button. Personally I didn't find that it detracted from the experience and actually makes sure you're paying attention to the battle and lets you contribute in some way. In true Double Fine fashion the writing (literally because there is no voice acting. Not a problem, just a statement) is top notch. Funny, witty, and endearing with jokes for both adults and children. Don't write off Costume Quest because of its apparently juvenile theme, you'd be missing out. It's fun, funny, and really is a nice departure from what you've probably played last. It doesn't over stay it's welcome and is well worth your time.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												Great fun, not at all what I usually play. I got it discounted and thought I'd give it a try. Funny and engaging dialogue, simple (but more complex at later stages) and customizable combat, and baased in a world of puzzles, secret chests and exploration, Costume Quest excels itself as both a children's game and one for adults.I am six hours through at the moment and just finished the main story. There is an expansion so I'm expecting total playtime to be about 10 hours. Not bad at all for the price.If you are a fan of RPGs, levelling up, area exploration, turn-based combat, or completionist gaming, there will be something here for you. I highly recommend it.

												Where to even begin with this one... Costume Quest is something special. The setting is superb and the RPG elements are interwoven brilliantly. content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												Costume Quest is an amusing, anime style, adventure game with some unique dynamics. Firstly, costumes you pick up become useful in the game world in two ways. One, they each have a unique ability, like the robot costume to boost your speed and let you jump off ramps, and secondly, they become genuine fighting equipment, changing your character into what the costume represents. Be it a knight, or a fancy big robot, the costumes have incredibly power in this fun and quirky game by the creators of Psychonauts. Definelty a fun little game to play, and a get a fresh taste of Double Fine on PC.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												This one was a surprise. When looking at some pictures, I wasn't expecting much, but was surprised by it. This game has what you can expect from Double Fine, very funny and well written dialogue, fun combat system and a nice world to explore. The biggest flaw of this game, is it's length and scope. It's a short game. But the 6-8 hours it will take you to complete it, will be fully enjoyed. The story, although quite simplistic, is fun and entertaining. The combat system is  very nice, it's a JRPG turn based system with some quick time events thrown in between. When you enter battle, you'll transform into the costume you're wearing, so if you're using a cardboard robot costume, in battle you turn into a full laser shooting robot. The game has a lot of costumes and all of them very different from each other so you'll have to consider what costumes are best for each character and each situation. To add even more diversity, you have battle stamps to collect and use. These give some additional passive abilities, and make a lot of difference in combat. The game has a very simple level system and currency (candy). You can use candy to buy some upgrades and stamps to further develop your character. All in all, this is a very good bur short RPG, and I recommend it to everyone who likes the genre.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												I don't want to hate on this game. I love the story. I love the characters. I love the dialogue. I love the art style.I hate grindy JRPG combat.Where 75% of your game time is spent in combat, it should be engaging; not a throwback to the NES era. After my fourth fight, I found myself avoiding enemies whenever possible. Not because of the difficulty, but because each fight is another 2-3 minute delay from that quest item that I was looking for in the game world. I challenge anyone to convince me that this style of combat makes the game fun.If there were a quarter as many enemies, and you used puzzle-solving to overcome them, this game would gel a lot better.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2012
												The whole game takes place on Halloween night where you must rescue your twin brother (or sister, depending on who you choose) who has been kidnapped by candy-stealing monsters. You have to trick-or-treat at every lighted house to unlock other areas in the game world. If a monster opens a door you will engage in a random turn-based battle where your costume powers will come in handy. On your quest you will meet other trick-or-treaters and pick up more followers for your search party. Collect candy from trash bags and smashed pumpkins which can be used to purchase perks in monster battles. Complete mini-quests to earn experience so you can level up. Do classic Halloween activities, like bob for apples and compete in a costume contest. Collect Creepy Treat trading cards and materials to unlock more costumes that have special abilities.It's a unique blend of rpg-ing and casual gameplay that perfectly captures the spirit of Halloween. A must-have for those too old to trick-or-treat.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												I like the idea for costume quest. The visional style fits very well with the game. The game has some fun characters too.What I don't like with the game is that it is extremely repetitive. The first area you are in was pretty fun. But it feels like the game might as well has ended there. Because you then get to another area where you have basically the same quests again, just at a different location. The quests aren't very fun either. The combat is very repetitive because only have one normal attack and a special attack that you get after two attacks. So every fight is: regular attack which follows with a quick time event to get the maximum damage out of your attack, do this for every character. Then quick time event to reduce damage from the enemy. Then repeat this to get special attack, do special attack. if the enemy isn't dead do it again. The concept for the game is very good. It could have been an awesome game. But sadly it's too repetitive and it kind of falls flat. Even though the game is very short is feels far to long for what the actual content of the game. It feels like they made the game longer by just using the same quest again with a new background texture.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												I usually try to stay away from stuff that is cute and kidsy, but this game is actually not really like that. It is a charming little game with really great graphic design and a good turn based rpg combat system like Final Fantasy style. You go around a town map doing quests and it is so far a lot of fun. Double Fine ♥♥♥♥ed up Iron Brigade bad which was really unfortunate, but they have a gem on their hands here with this game. The huge flaws in this game though is that it is very short (I beat the main game + the dlc in 7 hours), there is no replay value: once you beat it there is no reason to ever play it again, and it could also be more difficult. One of my favorite short playthroughs that I have played in a long time. I don't know why exactly but it just strikes a chord with me and I love it. I think because it reminds me of one of my favorite games of all time, Earthbound on the Super Nintendo. A very good game, just way too short. Catch it on sale and only on sale.

												High concept, bad executionLike all of Double Fine's games, this product is very stylish, but the actual gameplay is frustrating and glitchy. A turn-based battle system where you have to press keys to avoid attacks? I could never time them properly. So there you have it––a game themed around children and Halloween, that's too difficult and glitchy for kids to play. Do not buy.

												This game is just fantastic! It's a fun little halloween RPG by the amazing team at Double Fine, which are responsible for masterpieces like Psychonauts and Brutal Legend. It's a short and sweet game that i enjoyed from start to finish, even though the combat can get a bit repetitive in the start of the game, Once you get out of the first area of the game the combat becomes fresh again. Introducing new enemies, new costumes, and new abilities.It also has quite a bit of challenge, i didn't die a lot, but nearing the end of the game it really gets difficult.Overall it's a really good game. 9/10

content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												It's rare to see a game made by double fine with bland characters, obnoxious gameplay and boring story  however this game has all three. The combat system in this game is turn based with no strategy, that however I can stand I enjoy games like Final Fantasy or Pokemon, however Double Fine decided to "innovate" by mixing in Real Time Events which just completely ruined it for me. Similarly to Psychonauts and Brutal legend this game features collectibles, however unlike these 2 games - collectibles are not a side-quest but are the main quest of the game and you cannot proceed until you have searched every last corners for those collectibles. I don't know what happened to double fine but their earlier games were much better.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												Do you like classic JRPGs? Yes? Then you will surely like the innovative reaction games, quick-time events and whatnot, that are required for actually winning the battles! Costume Quest really requires the hard tactical experince of a person that can understand the difficult concepts of "a monster that heals other monsters" and "a monster that deals high damage". If those terms sound difficult to comprehend and you cannot understand why they should be the primary targets, you might be more at home with some lighter strategy games.

number of helpful: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												Here is another beauty that I got thanks to that Double Fine humble bundle. Every time I start thinking of going back to console gaming these bundles and steam sales just drag me right back in the glorious world of PC gaming and the silly and serious experiences it has to offer.Costume Quest is a game that I read and saw a decent amount of before I played it from the various videogame news sites that I follow. As a result I went into the game with a certain amount of expectations which were not entirely met if I am being honest.Costume Quest is a pretty mediocre game. Its definitely not bad, but its not that good either. If you are hoping to find a game that can be used as an eight to ten hour distraction then you should be fine getting Costume Quest. If you want something that is more than a distraction then you need to look elsewhere. Because while this game has a lot of charm, its very superficial in some major parts of its design leaving the experience of playing this game feeling boring and repetitive in more than one instance. This is something I feel pretty strongly about, to that point that I'm not looking forward to the sequel that Double Fine recently announced. Unless there are some major changes being made to the gameplay aspect of the game which I don't think is going to happen to be honest.If you feel like reading a more detailed review you can find it here: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2014/06/costume-quest.html.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												This is a game for kids, not kids-at-heart. I'm an adult, that likes Halloween. I like dressing up in costumes, and both handing out and having candy. I try to host a Halloween party every year.I got this game because I was hoping that there would be the same level of dialouge and characters as in Psychonauts. It's not.It's a very, very simplistic game, with choose a button and some QTE stuff. The costumes change things a bit, but anyone who has played any RPG type games at all can probably figure out the two damage dealers, one healer, or one tank, one damage, one healer, and not ever really need to switch costumes, besides to look at the different attacks.It's not a bad game for kids at all. The writing is still decent, and some of the jokes were amusing, but as an adult fan of Doublefine who purchased it for myself, I feel let down. It's also a very short game. Again, one that would more appeal to a kid audience.There IS a market for more adult-based Halloween costume style games out there that don't need horror or sex. I just wish Doublefine had realized that.

Posted: November 6, 2014
												This is a really fantastic light RPG. It has that signature Double Fine dialog and in general the feel you expect from them. Just like I mentioned in my Stacking review this has reasonable achievements and very good accomodation for the completionist type. Appropriate since both this and Stacking was written in either 2 weeks or 4 weeks (I forgot the story) as part of a company creativity exercise.It's really a shame that EA and LucasArts are such inept pieces of♥♥♥♥♥♥that they didn't capitalize on Double Fine during this period and allow them creative freedoms or the sequel to this would have came out much earlier and a Psychonauts sequel might actually exist. But oh well, great game overall and much of what I said about Stacking can be applied here. Double Fine knows you love to collect things and it knows that you love to 100% things, and they love you for loving those things and so accomodate you well.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												This game is all about the charm. The story isn't the same ol' derivative RPG story. The characters & setting are very enjoyable. I especially enjoyed playing this during Halloween, It put me in the holiday spirit.As an RPG there's nothing truely ground breaking here. The combat is ok, It's a class based system. Classes are selected through a series of costumes. Some costumes have healing abilities, some are damage/crowd control & others are defensive. It may sound unique & interesting, but the battles generally all go the same way due to the fact that your abilities are not able to be activated till the 3rd round. Damage for 3 rounds, if the enemy is still up, stun heal & damage battle over.I'm a fan of Tim Schafer's work, but I'm going to rate his work on it's own merits. This game is fun & charming & I would recommend it, but I would say wishlist it & wait for a sale.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
This review explains how Double Fine's Costume Quest is a shallow, repetitive, featureless example of the RPG adventure game genre.[. . .] You do 1-3 identical attacks, then 1-3 identical dodges, and on every third turn special moves. That’s the only combat rhythm, and you’ll be doing it until every battle is a chore. There are no combos; no combat varieties; no difficult build decisions; no in-battle items; and, except for ‘go for the priest first,’ there is no strategy. number of helpful: 3 of 11 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												One of the better examples of why indy developers should be allowed to exist, unfortunately several flaws in this game prevent recommendation.Technically, the game has limited resolution modes and generally doesn't behave like a PC game.  Being unaware of foreground windowing prevents foreground switching and causes the game to crash... that's ok, developers probably weren't aware that DirectX 3.0 was introduced in 1997, so it's understandable they wouldn't have bothered to test the game under Windows. Artwork is 3D which at least beats going 2D platformer, but it's still extremely low effort.Gameplay quickly becomes stale and repetitive, which is the only chance the developers had in way of apology for their negligence on the artwork and on making the game compatible with Windows. Simply too hard to approve.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4
												Wow.   Looked so great.  However, after playing for an hour I'm done.  To start with, the controls are counter-intuative and difficult to control.   They feel like they were ported from a game controller game.  Anyways, on a PC they don't work well.The plot is text based and the text bubbles move by -very- rapidly even for a fast reader..  Don't even try to read them outloud if playing in a group.    If you are distracted for a moment, you don't get to read what each character says.  Durning game play you must complete some tasks that require you to move accurately and quickly.  If you fail the task you start again.  Nothing spells "fun" like repeating a task that is only difficult because the controls are poor.In any event, after less than an hour's game play - this feels like a quick and dirty port of a console game with little testing for the PC market.  Shame, look fun, good concept, nice graphics.Horrible game play due to a quick, poorly done port.  Wish I could get my $10 back.

number of helpful: 6 of 17 people (35%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												Yeah, I'm really going to suffer through a bunch of idiotic tutorial dialogue one speech bubble at a time with no option to skip to the next line when I'm done reading. It's really good and well-thought-out that all the "important" conversations give me two options: 1) stare at text bubble long after im finished reading it or 2) skip entire conversation by pressing escape. I'm using sarcasm btw. I'm being sarcastic. I am utilizing a sarcastic tone to convey the opposite meaning of the literal definition of my words. In truth, the instant the last Steam Trading Card drops I'm going to be quitting and immediately deleting local content.If the dialogue was at-all interesting maybe it'd be worth sitting still through the horribly-paced cutscenes, but every conversation is Nick Jr. level garbage, dripping with that awful, condescending slime of Idiotic Childrens' Programming for Idiotic Children. It's patronizing, unimaginatively hokey, constantly condescending and utterly unbearable.It's also really insanely good that the unimportant "flavor" conversations CAN be skipped one bubble at a time, thus proving that the designers were capable of implementing this feature, but for whatever reason they then decided all the Extremely Important Cutscene Dialogue needed to be read at a speed of approximately one speech bubble every thirty seconds.Also the overworld control is pretty clunky (with a strange "momentum pause" when switching directions 90 degrees at a time) - probably feels a lot better on a controller, but WASD for life. Thankfully I'm probably not going to end up being horribly horribly frustrated by it because I don't plan on actually playing this game. The battles are moderately cool I guess if you're into Final Fantasy and/or QTE-styled fights (press key to select thing, press key when slider is in the sweet spot to do thing) and maybe the costume mechanics are good, maybe they're terrible, I'm unfortunately never going to find out because every two minutes I'm interrupted by a cutscene that I end up completely skipping once my patience runs out, so I end up further and further separated from the most "important" plot elements or story goals or whatever these cutscenes are intended to convey.In the interests of pointing out the positives: The graphics are very nice and colorful, and since there's no voice-acting there's no terrible voice-acting to either disable or bîtch about the inability to disable.Recommended for slow readers, fans of terrible cinematic pacing, and lobotomy patients.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												costume quest is a pretty neat rpg done in the spirit of halloween. i must say this is a great rpg for gamers new and old. there is no item managing that hardcore rpg games have which means young and old both can enjoy this game without worry of having to run back to the store. there is a store in game though which has battle cards with varying effects u can use equip each charecter with 1 card swappable outside of battle.  healing wise there is none other then in battle so no worrys of dieing from being unprepared.one of the toughest parts about this game is prob the boss battles aside from that the trying to get every defense and attack perfect by pressing the right button. also to talk about the battles pretty simple just attack and defend before the enemy hits you u try to press the correct button if hit the correct one critical attack and in defense better defense or a dodge and if right card equiped counter. after 3 turns ur specials charged which they are pretty nice addition. but do not take the game lightly u can lose battles if ur not careful. but there is no such thing as gameover in this game it just places u in the area right before the battle <3also to note there is a varity of costumes which u have to find the parts to make them each comes with a special ablity which is pretty neat. oh and there is special ablitys for some of them useable in the field which adds to the fun.now if u like rpgs that arent that tough yet still fun give costume quest a go as its worth a play and i would say a replay <3   oh and did i mention candy? TONS OF CANDY!so grab costume quest and help stop the evil witch and the monsters from stealing all of the candy before its too late and halloween is ruined!   ~ will be updating after finish the dlc quest grubbins on ice that came with :3just finished the dlc grubbins on ice make sure u collect every costume before playing it and load same slot u finished in, as u will have all of the orignal costumes then ^w^ its like costume quest turned christmas quest. basicly the same gameplay new areas and new costumes and areas. also do note finish costume quest then the dlc as seems it leads into game 3 ^w^if this review is not helpful, please leave a comment as to why u feel that way so i may make changes if needed ^w^

Posted: December 13, 2013
												I bought this because a game based on trick or treating sounded really great. However, trick or treating has never been so lame. The game gets off to a good start and is plenty of fun, but there's nothing to keep it interesting. Going door to door collecting candy even got horribly boring after a while. The combat system was easy but it was also a snore. It was so over done that I started just avoiding enemies. The whole thing is so tedious and repetitive, performing the same actions again and again (trick or treating and fighting enemies), that by the time I got to what would be considered the first boss, I was sick of this game and thoroughly done with it.

Posted: March 24, 2013
												I wish I'd waited a week - this was 11.49 when I got it and now its 5.74. But, didn't know it was going to happen. In relation to the game itself, its probably worth more like the 5.74. The characters are adorable, the premise is clever, but the gameplay is bad. I appreciate that this was done during studio downtime to waste some time but knowing how awesome Double Fine are, it surpised me just how bad the gameplay was.  I got it because I love Tim, I love Double Fine, and I ADORE Halloween. But this is pretty painful. I can't tolerate it anymore and I am afriad that I have wasted 12 quid. Shame. Maybe nearer to Halloween I can give it another go but I doubt it.

Posted: April 20, 2014
												This game does some things wonderfully. It's a fantastic portrayal of the way a costume transforms you from a kid wearing a bucket or a cardboard box into a powerful figure who kicks♥♥♥♥♥and stands up for justice. The moment of suspense after you knock on the door when you don't know who or what is behind it is a really nice touch. The cel-shaded models in the battle scenes look great.But do be aware this is a very _simple_ game. It could be a good introduction to the CRPG genre for younger players, but there's not much depth to be found here. The story is charming but simple. There is some variety in the abilities you get with the costumes and accessories, but there's no skill progression to speak of, and each party member may only have a single accessory. The tactically-minded will find there's an accessory you can get mid-game that lets you cheese your way through fights for everything except bosses.So the thumbs-up here is a potential thumbs-up if you're looking for a game for your kids. If you're old enough to have your own Steam account, you've probably outgrown this.

												It's a little slow at first but once you're used to the game (when you're in the mall) it's a lot better. Posted: September 14, 2013
												Costume Quest, like any Double Fine and Tim Schafer game, is just great. It has that sort of charm that games like Psychonauts, Monkey Island, and Grim Fandango all have. The writing, characters, and story in CQ is what draws you in and keeps you in. The gameplay/combat is very interesting at first, but after maybe halfway through the game, I stumbled on a method of conducting battles that had a very rinse & repeat feeling to it. You may not experience it, and it can easily be avoided simply through player choice, so I wont harp on that too much, but the combat is the game's weakest point. It's a fun little ride and well worth it at any price.4/5

Posted: January 16, 2012
												A cutesy, simplistic RPG?  Meh.  Tell me Tim Schafer's had a hand in development?  Well, as little of Psychonauts that I've played, that's an interesting factoid but doesn't sell me.  All the moves in battle have action commands a la Super Mario RPG?  Now I'm listening.This is an engaging game.  Cute, but Tim Schafer cute with adult overtones.  Like Psychonauts, the landscapes are built for exploration and look great.  Battles couldn't be any more basic, but the need to react to quick time-esque button presses to either boost attacks or minimize incoming damage keeps you on your toes.  Each costume you acquire is unique and works differently in battles, making it fun to experiment and find the perfect combination for your play style.  It's short, no more than six hours, but it's actually the perfect length.  Maybe it's not worth the full asking price, but if Costume Quest comes up in a Steam sale...  grab it.  And let candy gluttony take you on a fun little journey.

Posted: May 11, 2013
												Remember when you were a kid and you played pretend in a costume, especially around Halloween? Well in this game you really do become your costume to fight off monsters and save your twin sibling from an evil witch and her army of candy-stealing grubbins on Halloween Night.Cutesy and silly, but with some clever jokes and some really fun combat. You unlock new powers by making new costumes using found items. Whether thats a Giant Robot that shoots chest missles at monsters, a unicorn that heals it's allies with rainbow magic, or a french fry crab (note: I'm serious) that stuns enemies by shooting superheated salt crystals at them there's lots of neat combinations for every battle.Double Fine is one of my favorite game companies these days and the unique and unusual titles they come up with are the reason why. In an industry mostly dominated by gritty realistic shooter games, blood soaked sci-fi shooter games, and football its nice to see a company that goes against the norm.

Posted: May 2, 2014
												Want to play a eastern style rpg but can't be having with all that spiky or multicoloured hair? Want an rpg with a sense of humour? Like Halloween?You, Sir, have very specific tastes. Thankfully Costume Quest ticks all those boxes.Costume Quest is by Double Fine, the company that brought Psychonauts, Brutal Legend, Stacking and, more recently, Broken Age. It's a pretty good lineage to come from.You play as one of a pair of siblings, the sister Wren or the brother Reynold. Whichever of the two, you choose the other will get kidnapped and it's your job to rescue them.Along the way you will collect companions, complete minor quests and collect items to construct other costumes. Why would you want to do that you may ask? Well, beside acquiring the achievement for doing so, it will also give you some more options for combat and exploring the game world.Each costume has abilities when you go into combat wearing them. They can roughly be divided into three types (though some will span multiple types); Offence, Support and finally Defence.As you complete quests and fight your characters will level up and gain Battle Stamps. These stamps add extra abilities or buff your characters and winning the game is near impossible without them.The combat is in the style of an eastern style rpg. Your enemies stand on one side of the screen, you on the other and you take turns attacking each other. You defend yourself through a QTE (quick time event), which if you press the correct button on time will lessen the damage taken. Basic attacks are similar to the defence, you wait  for the prompt to mash a button, wiggle a stick or or just press the right button at the right time and if your successful you'll be rewarded with a critical hit. As you fight your costumes special abilities will charge up (usually around the 3rd turn). These attacks don't have a QTE and, depending on the costume, do great damage with an added effect, heal or protect.Try as I might I can't really fault the game. It's a little short but it's not exactly breaking the bank when it comes to buying it. You could easily complete the game and it's DLC (complete with all achievements for those that care for them) in a weekend.I recommend this game very highly, it's asking price isn't even that high for what it provides you.

Posted: September 3, 2012
												Another fun and offbeat game from the folks at Double Fine. Its Halloween and hi-jinks are afoot, you play a group of kids out to rescue the main characters sibling who has been captured by an evil witch. Combat is of the turn based variety you are used to seeing in Japanese Style RPG's, your party on one side and the enemy on the other. Hey, come back here, its not dull at all, you see, the kids you have in your party? They can transform into the costumes they are wearing, dressed as a knight? Bam you are a knight in shining armour dealing blows with your sword. Dressed as a robot? Suddenly you are as huge as Voltron and dealing some serious harm. Its the kind of wish fulfilment any kid has when they dressed up as a kid and Double Fine tap into that nostalgic vibe with their usual charm and whimsy. If I have a complaint its minor and its simply that the combat can get a little repetetive, but thats more a flaw in the nature of this style of combat than any glaring fault on Double Fine's part. That little gripe aside, the humour and tongue in cheek Halloween take make this another good addition to Double Fine's stable. That said, pick Iron Brigade or Stacking first if your Double Fine collection is lacking those, this is a fine game but those are musts.

												Costume Quest was one of the game(s) that I was able to watch my significant other play and watch her have the time of her life.Costume Quest suprisingly is quiet difficult for ( what seems ) like a game for younger crowd, it requires strategy when it comes to combat from - What is the best 'lay-out' to the best attacks and when to use them. I found the combat system reminded me a lot of Final Fantasy system, which I really enjoyed with this game. Pros : - Great gameplay- Funny commentary- Great feel to the combat system- Story-line was interestingCons : - (Seems) like this game could be difficult for the younger crowd.- Too short! Wish I could have more to play!!Over and all; if you are considering this game...Get it! Well worth your dollars!9.5/10

Posted: May 2, 2014
												Want to play a eastern style rpg but can't be having with all that spiky or multicoloured hair? Want an rpg with a sense of humour? Like Halloween?You, Sir, have very specific tastes. Thankfully Costume Quest ticks all those boxes.Costume Quest is by Double Fine, the company that brought Psychonauts, Brutal Legend, Stacking and, more recently, Broken Age. It's a pretty good lineage to come from.You play as one of a pair of siblings, the sister Wren or the brother Reynold. Whichever of the two, you choose the other will get kidnapped and it's your job to rescue them.Along the way you will collect companions, complete minor quests and collect items to construct other costumes. Why would you want to do that you may ask? Well, beside acquiring the achievement for doing so, it will also give you some more options for combat and exploring the game world.Each costume has abilities when you go into combat wearing them. They can roughly be divided into three types (though some will span multiple types); Offence, Support and finally Defence.As you complete quests and fight your characters will level up and gain Battle Stamps. These stamps add extra abilities or buff your characters and winning the game is near impossible without them.The combat is in the style of an eastern style rpg. Your enemies stand on one side of the screen, you on the other and you take turns attacking each other. You defend yourself through a QTE (quick time event), which if you press the correct button on time will lessen the damage taken. Basic attacks are similar to the defence, you wait  for the prompt to mash a button, wiggle a stick or or just press the right button at the right time and if your successful you'll be rewarded with a critical hit. As you fight your costumes special abilities will charge up (usually around the 3rd turn). These attacks don't have a QTE and, depending on the costume, do great damage with an added effect, heal or protect.Try as I might I can't really fault the game. It's a little short but it's not exactly breaking the bank when it comes to buying it. You could easily complete the game and it's DLC (complete with all achievements for those that care for them) in a weekend.I recommend this game very highly, it's asking price isn't even that high for what it provides you.

Posted: March 18, 2014
												As one of two twins, who are new in town, you set out into the Halloween night to trick-or-treat your neighbours - just to find your sibling abducted by REAL monsters! And, 'cause it's Halloween, no adults realize it's real monsters. Collect candy, trading cards, costumes and explore three rich and exciting areas to rescue your sibling, before your parents get all up in yo biz.So, now down to brass tacks. Is it any good? Well. The graphic style of this adventure RPG is stunning, the level design is flawless, the gameplay is great fun and the battlesystem is thought through. Sure, the battles can be quite monotone in the last half hour of the game, but it's manageable due to exciting skill tree choices; your skills in battle change depending on what costume you have one. The achievement are challenging but manageable, which makes the game replayable. It's an hommage to the imagination of kids and to Halloween. I really recommend it.8/10, the only downsides are the repetetive combats.

Posted: April 8, 2014
												Alright, Costume Quest. Pretty charming. It is a JRPG set in a halloween theme. As it seems to be the usual thing about Double Fine productions, the artstyle and designs of pretty much everything in the whole thing is very good pretty and nice for the theme. That is very good. You gotta love Double Fine for that pattern by the way. The story is also funny and children friendly, no voice actors, so you have to read, which is not bad, except if you are foreign. However, it is a JRPG and that is a genre, that seriously is pretty old. Something not that good. They have to be congratulated however for not putting in linear corridors or random encounters, but the combat is still really simple, gets boring and gives not really any punishment for defeat. I wonder why they even put in a run away button. So the combat is pretty much just padding, but since Double Fine is, as far as I know, an indie game company, it can slide. It also has a lot of side quests and collectibles. Nothing for me, but you might enjoy it. The innovation is the costumes, which is easy to change between, and it gives a lot of different fighting styles and problem solving. The puzzles are however pretty much told how to solve, so no bonus there. In conclusion, Costume Quest is nothing ground breaking, but as someone who does not like mainstream JRPG it is alright. It will be the same for people who likes JRPG. It is like a little nice twix bar, that you eat fastly, and it is alright, but you will very soon forget it. If you have kids, buy this to them, because there are not that many good kid games, besides lego i suppose. If you want it for yourself, you can do a lot worse, but if you have not played Psychonauts, save the extra buck and buy that first, because it is a lot more ground breaking and creative.

Posted: December 5, 2015
  What better way to spend a few hours than pummeling monsters as a giant rainbow unicorn?  Costume Quest is a fun, youthful, and humorous adventure that utilizes overworld exploration, puzzle solving, and a simple turn-based combat system. I would recomend it to children, people looking for a not-scary halloween game, and anyone who would like to nostagically relearn some of the magic of halloween.This game does a lot of things well and a few things not so well. Good Stuff:  Concept  - I love the sheer idea of this game. A group of kids must use their costumes that ACTUALLY TRANSFORM THE WEARERS to fight monsters, save a sibling, and collect tons of candy along the way. It sounds like all of my childhood halloween fantasies at once. Story  - Less predicatable than one might image. It has just enough twists to keep it interesting, but manages to keep it simple enough for a younger person to enjoy it. Characters  - Likeable child characters are comparable to black republicans nowadays: maybe there's one or two here and there, but overall they're pretty rare. The children in this game are highly likeable and funny, which is a metaphorical breath of fresh air. Humour  - My inner 10 year old got a real kick out of this game. The jokes are silly and childish, but I'd be lying if I said I didn't laugh quite a bit during my playthrough. I wish more games could imbue such a good sense of humour into their games. Stuff That Was Ok:  Music  - It wasn't exactly a synphonic masterpiece, but it does add to the immersion. My only qualm is that the battle music can get a bit repettitive. World/Map  - Again, it wasn't mind blowing or pioneering or anything like that. Each area is pretty different, which does well to break up any monotony. Some environmental objects (specifically, ramps) can feel really clunky, but all-in-all it doesn't affect the enjoyment of the game. Stuff I Wish Was Different:  Character Progression  - I believe that the Devs wanted to create a simple RPG that was less about combat and leveling up and more about the story. They absolutely succeeded, so props to them. I do wish that there would have been a slightly more in-depth character upgrade system, but that's just me. Combat  - Like I said above, the game isn't really combat or skill focused. The combat is simple and easy to learn, which is good. The problem with simple combat is that it can get very, very repetitive. I was actually somewhat sad when the thought "ugh, do I really have to fight these guys?" came to mind, because to me it meant that the combat had gotten boring. It's worth noting that I was admittedly about 3/4 of the way through before that happened. Lighting  - My last minor complaint is the lighting in the game. For the majority of the game, the Devs did a great job of keeping the overall lighting pretty low, but bright enough to see where you were going and to find the things you needed to find. However, the  first part of the 2nd act and the upper two floors of the mall area  are just too dark. There is a brightness option in the menu, but amping up the brightness seems almost to be cheating, since part of the game's charm is the comic-spookiness of low lighting. That's really my only complaint on the world design. Final Summation:   I really did enjoy this game. It was a fun way to spend a few hours, and it made me think back to my childhood dreams about being the costume I wore on halloween. Would recommend.

Posted: March 16, 2016
												It's Halloween.  You're out trick or treating, and your brother/sister gets kidnapped!  It turns out that there is a plot by real monsters to steal all the candy in the world, and only you and your friends can stop them.Your costumes have different abilities to use while you're walking around town.  One has a flashlight so you can cross dark areas.  One has a helmet so you can cross areas with dripping water or debris.  One lets you roller skate and jump off ramps.  Another lets you into a secret club in your neighborhood.The costumes become REAL during combat, and each has a different fighting style.  So if you're dressed as the Statue of Liberty, you can use a healing spell to restore HP to the whole group, or you can hit the enemy with your torch to set them on fire.  If you are the robot, you can rocket-punch a single enemy or use your missiles to attack all the enemies.  And the other costumes have additional things going for them.  As you play more of the game, you will find parts of new costumes.  Only if you find all the parts can you make the costume.  In addition to changing costumes, you can also buy badges that give additional abilities.  One lets you add a little poison to your attacks.  Another adds a bigger poison with splash damage to nearby enemies.  Another boosts your HP so you live longer.  Another boosts your damage, but only if you make a critical hit.  You make a critical hit by getting good timing when you push the button displayed on screen.  Critical hits are very easy, I think I only ever missed two.  The first was because I didn't know how to do it yet, the second was because I sneezed and it messed up my timing.This game is not particularly difficult.  It is also not very big or long.  Still, it is fun for a little while.  It also has an expansion pack (standalone) where the kids visit the monster world at Christmas time and help the monsters overthrow a dictator.  New costumes are available in the expansion.  You can load your end-game save from the original game and start with the same characters, badges, and costumes when you boot up the expansion.Bottom line:  it's cute and fun, but don't expect too much from this one.

Posted: November 11, 2015
												I was expecting much less about Costume Quest... When I first saw it, I thought it'd be something childish, but I gave it a try, so I bought the CQ1&2 Bundle for a low price.I couldn't have been more wrong... Costume Quest was awesome!When I realized it, I was extremely immersed in the story and the gameplay... Though I thought some maps and objectives were a little repetitive, but no harm done.One of the things that made me really like this game was the costume system, the need-to-get-that-costume feeling is really engaging!This game is really good for those who want a not-so-difficult but fun and good RPG experience. The achievements are very easy to get, too.Extremely recommend it.

Posted: September 14, 2015
												At first this game seemed to childish, and I thought it would be rather lacking in gameplay, but I was proven wrong. The gameplay is fun, the item collecting is relatively challenging, and getting all the achievements made the entire experience feel rewarding.-PROS-*tons of characters to play as (as in costumes you can use to fight in)*an exciting reflex-style version of fighting (hit the commands to execute criticals)*humorous dialogue*wide explorable levels with interesting obstacles and secrets*references are abundant in many places, if you keep your eyes open!-cons- (and constructive criticisms)*The characters walk a bit slow, and to speed them up you need to use the Robot's skate-shoes. Only problem is, while doing this (if you find the robot not to your liking during combat) you can end up stuck as the robot during and upcoming fights.*Switching between costumes on the main character can be a bit annoying. It would make gameplay a little less annoying if you could equip different costumes to all 3 characters, then switch between characters for fast exploration trait usage.*Lack of facial animation. While it may have been intentional, and there are some emote-style expressions, it feels as if the animations aren't quite as developed in the real world of the game as they could be. There are many expressions used during combat for enemies, and for the costume fighters, but it doesn't really make up for the lack of facial animations in the game's explorable world.All in all, I rate this about an 8.5/10    -  Great game, could use some minor improvements, but all-in-all a great game.I highly recommend people play this if you like RPGs with a twist.

Posted: February 24, 2013
												Another Double Fine game that lives up to its developer's name. The game comes with a second quest so you're really getting two games in one. Costume Quest is an exploration game with turn-based battle segments. As a kid fighting goblins to rescue their twin, yoou go door to door trick-or-treating trying to clear an area of candy to advance ot the next. It's very much like a "my first RPG" kind of game, but it's still a rewarding experience. You'll feel like a kid again.

Posted: September 25, 2015
												Usually when you think of a Halloween game, you think of a scary game, and those are all well and good; but what about a game that really brings the magic of Halloween itself? You know, costumes, trick or treating, having fun with your friends? Costume Quest somehow does it and does it very well. The first level already brims with nostalgia of days gone by (for me anyway) of walking the neighborhood at night and going door to door with a pale for the candy. You may wonder what the gameplay is like - well, first off the story is not serious, it's a light-hearted romp that'll make you smile for all ages. The overall story begins as your brother or sister (depending on who you choose to play as) gets kidnapped by strange monsters who love candy, and you are going to rescue them. The gameplay itself mostly is you going door to door in various places, and sometimes you get an adult with candy (which is like a currency in the game), or it could be a monster, which whom you have to fight.The fighting is done like a turn-based RPG, and you can get little things to help you out, called Battle Stamps. Each stamp has a unique ability you can use, each of your character gets one stamp per person, but you can switch them out if you don't care for it.There's no real dying in the game, you lose a battle, and you can just try again. The settings are really fun, like a neighborhood with various decorations, or a mall etc. The humor is really good, and adults and children will enjoy it, it's really a game for the family. Sadly, there's no co-op but it's fun on its own.There's also the DLC "Grubbins on Ice" included which adds 1-2 hours more. The core game isn't TOO long even getting everything, maybe 4-5 hours? But it's a lot of fun, and if you want to feel that Halloween nostalgia, this is the perfect game for you! The sequel is also very good, and worth checking out if you like the first one.

												Short answer, yes, i higly recommend it.And the long one:Costume Quest is a light-hearted rpg game, made by one of my favorites developers, Double Fine. The game mechanics are really nice, there are a great variety of costumes and somewhat variable enemies. My only complaint regarding the gameplay is that the fighting mechanics get a little bit repetitive due to some unskipable animations, but nothing too big. Some peaple reported some bugs, but i haven't found any in my playtrough. The game story is light-hearted, but good and there are some really nice jokes. The game's graphics are a cartoonish style and are really well polished and beautifull. I really loved the game, it's a really escape from the same repetitive game formula of nower days, It is somewhat short, I took about 5 hours to finish it, and i'm usually slower than the average to beat a game (It took me about 4 hours to beat the DLC grubbings ice). 												I am completely in love with this game. Posted: August 28, 2012
												If you've ever wanted a game that's almost exactly like Paper Mario, only themed around Halloween instead of the Mushroom Kingdom, you're in luck.  The gameplay is nearly identical in most respects (run around completing simple tasks, gain stamps/costumes/badges/levels to improve your characters, start combat with monsters by whacking them on the main screen, then go into turn-based battles with timed attack/defense commands), but it's fun and light-hearted, not too difficult, and has a good sense of humor, i.e. Double Fine Halloween Paper Mario.  Play it with a controller, or you'll be sad.  And not that the art style doesn't look good already, but if your video card can handle it, enable the "secret" command-line SSAA mode (-ssaa2x or -ssaa4x) and it looks fantastic.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												From the makers of Psychonauts, Costume Quest is an interesting and creative Halloween-themed RPG. You play as a group of imaginative children trying to stop the monsters of Repugia from stealing all of the candy on All Hallows' Eve. The battles are turn-based and simplistic enough so that even those who are new to the genre can get a hang of things quickly. The Cartoonish visuals are well done and perfect for this style of game. The writing is also quite humorous and exactly what you'd expect from Double Fine Productions. As long as you don't go into Costume Quest expecting a full-fledged RPG with a deep combat/inventory system, I think you can have quite a good time playing it. It's a fun and original game with entertaining battles and a lot of charm.

Posted: September 14, 2015
												At first this game seemed to childish, and I thought it would be rather lacking in gameplay, but I was proven wrong. The gameplay is fun, the item collecting is relatively challenging, and getting all the achievements made the entire experience feel rewarding.-PROS-*tons of characters to play as (as in costumes you can use to fight in)*an exciting reflex-style version of fighting (hit the commands to execute criticals)*humorous dialogue*wide explorable levels with interesting obstacles and secrets*references are abundant in many places, if you keep your eyes open!-cons- (and constructive criticisms)*The characters walk a bit slow, and to speed them up you need to use the Robot's skate-shoes. Only problem is, while doing this (if you find the robot not to your liking during combat) you can end up stuck as the robot during and upcoming fights.*Switching between costumes on the main character can be a bit annoying. It would make gameplay a little less annoying if you could equip different costumes to all 3 characters, then switch between characters for fast exploration trait usage.*Lack of facial animation. While it may have been intentional, and there are some emote-style expressions, it feels as if the animations aren't quite as developed in the real world of the game as they could be. There are many expressions used during combat for enemies, and for the costume fighters, but it doesn't really make up for the lack of facial animations in the game's explorable world.All in all, I rate this about an 8.5/10    -  Great game, could use some minor improvements, but all-in-all a great game.I highly recommend people play this if you like RPGs with a twist.

Posted: June 14, 2015
												This game is a tricky treat, in that the good, bad and ugly all relate to how Costume Quest definitely is not aimed at the "core gamer". If you spent tons of money on the latest gamer periphery, value your kill stats above all else and enjoy tons of gore - look elsewhere.After all this story is about kids and  seems fairly suitable for kids. In fact, I was thinking about giving this a Halloween run this year with a nephew of mine, but then realized one of the game's biggest shortcoming may be that it isn't voiced. That'll limit it's utility as a fun scary story for younger kids. Oh well.The game features some pretty nifty concepts (such as Trick-or-Treating being basically a core game mechanic), offers a combat system that is modern (with various abilitites and quick time events), yet fairly accessible (casual gamers will get the hang right quick), and a scary-cute graphics style that really is key to making it work. Okay, the game isn't perfect (if some of the costumes have any use beyong unlocking that 21st achievement, I haven't stumble across it; they simply feel bad in combat), and is more adventure than RPG length.Still. Costume Quest is well balanced for more casual gamers, has a very unique story and some nifty ideas. It may not quite be for "core gamers", but beyond that, it's for everyone.

Posted: June 14, 2015
												A ~6 hour adventure/RPG that's fueled by a Halloween setting and the cutest of art direction. Enter combat by trick or treating or just by approaching enemies in the world as they stroll. Combat takes place on a battleground where your costume 'comes to life'. Due to how hackneyed and simple the combat is it does get repetitive quite quickly. In saying that, some of the abilities are hilarious. The costumes are fun and interesting but shout-out to the American costume for having one of the best abilities i've ever seen which gets a giggle out of me every time. All in all it isn't a revolutionary game. It's repetitive but it's one of the most endearing, charm oozing games out there.

Posted: May 6, 2015
												Wow, what a great game.  It's a sleeper hit, in that it hits you under the chin like a sock puppet over a mailed fist.  Unexpected.  Total surprise. Sure, the gameplay is a little simplistic: poke around for candy, knock on doors, trip up monsters, turn-based party fight; rinse, repeat (with the occasional break to equip interesting items or use a cool costume power).  It is more than enjoyable enough to be forgiven any repetitiveness, and indeed serves to grease the wheels of the game's main attraction -- the fantastic story!Buy this game.

Posted: August 28, 2015
												Costume Quest with its add-on Grubbins on Ice is a nice Halloween-themed almost-RPG. It's, in one word, candy. I like candy.I highly recommend using a controller with this game. Keyboard controls felt pretty odd.Achievement Hint: The game doesn't know the date. It asks your machine for the date.+ Creepy Treats (collectibles) design+ Non-irritating but forgettable music+ Back To The Future discovery sound+ Costumes with exploration effects in addition to battle effects+ Costume battle action design0 no map0 Mostly inconsequential Battle Stamps (buffs)0 Level caps- Incorrect Battle Stamp descriptions- Pretty linear- Almost consistently no challenge- No description on save slots when loading- After the main game we see the credits headlined "Grubbins on Ice"Technically the game is about quasi-isometric exploration with battle intermezzi.The battles are similar to those associated with RPG-Maker games or for example Final Fantasy 7 but instead of action meters there is simply a battle order. Without fail, first your up to three character attack, then the up to three enemies - repeat until defeat.Although this may sound dry, the game is surprisingly fun. I played the game for maybe 11 hours, got stuck twice for a total of about 90 Minutes (misunderstood game mechanics in the beginning + final boss in the add-on) and it was entertaining enough to feel like around 4 hours.This is mostly due to a number of good design decision. For me, the game wasn't so much about the main storyline but more about your party of characters speaking with each other, other inhabitants of the area and enemies, and it was about the battles. For some reason those things made me think, I'd like to play this in a Spongebob Squarepants world, at one point.In order of relevance the advancements in the game are: gaining companions, completing new costumes and getting Battle Stamps. Ultimately progress in the game requires the player to win fights (actually you go trick-or-treating but half the time that results in fights) but there are a number of obstacles that require you to explore beforehand.*Companions*Companions come with a new costume and provide an extra action per round in battle.*Costumes*You get costumes with characters or you are given a blueprint which sort of tells you, by way of a somewhat indiscriminate outline, which three components/materials you need to complete the costume. Components are unique and can be found in more or less hidden treasure chests, given to you by inhabitants of the world, and maybe, I don't quite remember, be part of battle spoils. Once a costume is complete, it can be assigned to any of your characters.Half of the costumes come with an Exploration Ability, i.e. an ability that can and (with the exception of one  costume in the add-on) must be used in the exploration part of the game. The most important ability is the Boost that you get with your very first costume. The Boost allows your party to speed across the area and is essential to the pacing of the game. At one point or another, the player is likely to miss something plus there is a little back and forth in the game anyway. Without the Boost ability that could have easily turned into a chore - very good design decision.All of the costumes but one have a Combat Ability, i.e. a special that needs two battle rounds to load and can be executed instead of a normal attack.Apart from having an effect on game-play the costumes just look cool. Even if there wasn't an achievement connected to that I'd still recommend to take every costume into battle at least once. I simply like the progression of the costumes from the materials you have to collect over the (not really) crappy "not quite there" or "Dad did the best he could" design of the costume as the characters are wearing it in exploration mode to the awesome "this is how the kids see it" (or maybe "this is what adult think how the kids see it") design in battle, character design and attacks.*Buffs*Battle Stamps are buffs that can be assigned to your party's characters, one each. Buffs include boosts to health, defence, dodging, counter-attacks, the over-powerful stun and the underwhelming auto-revive - usually buffs are passive. I basically stuck to the same buffs throughout the game, occasionally upgrading when a better version of the buff turned up.Unfortunately, some of the buffs have misleading descriptions, most irritatingly the auto-revive is supposed to revive a character after one round. While this is technically correct a more apt description would explain, the character is revived after two rounds (one round after one round, see?). I only ever tried the buff when I had trouble with the final boss in the add-on and having a character inactive for two rounds is just unacceptable in that fight.*Collectibles*The Creepy Treats are mostly just nice-to-have. You collect them mainly as battle spoils and sometimes trade them with inhabitants. I guess they are mostly original ideas, e.g. Licorice Cables, Chocolate Hamburgers, Coconuts & Bolts, Misfortune Cookies.*Battles*As said before, each round in battle has your character(s) act first, then the up to three enemies. Usually, rounds go on until one side is defeated. In theory, there is an option to run away but I haven't tried it yet.Each round each character chooses one of standard attack, the costume's Combat Ability (if ready) or the Battle Stamp buff (if active). Standard attacks have QTEs connected to them. There is a number of different QTEs, i.e. hitting a specific, dynamic button in time, hitting a specific, dynamic button on time, moving the left analogue stick around, and repeatedly pressing a specific, dynamic button. The type of QTE is dependent on the costume. If you pass the QTE, the character deals 50% more damage.Combat Abilities need two rounds to load so they can be used every third round. They are usually a tactical option and it's not always useful to use them right away. For some reason, attack buffs do not affect Combat Abilities. This may even make the standard attack a preferable option overall.Some Battle Stamp active buffs can be executed instead of a standard attack. Of those the most powerful are likely the different stun abilities which can take a single enemy out of the fight for up to two rounds. Except for bosses, the later game can be played without ever getting hit by an enemy. This is very powerful since even a "failed" enemy attack can take as much as 25% of a characters live away.Some Combat Abilities can prevent almost all damage to characters.Enemies mostly do standard attacks which lead to a defensive QTE which, on success, prevents half of the damage to the character. Magically inclined enemies can heal, buff attack or defence of one of the enemies.Battles are pretty short and easy but fun, largely because of the costumes. *Game Experience*A few more words on the game. One of the rather negative aspects about the game is its linearity. Bring me this and that or you cannot go on, fight those guys or you cannot go on, complete a costume or you cannot go on. But this is well compensated by the entertainment factor.Even though of limited use, I'd have liked a map to come with each area. This was sort of addressed in the add-on where you gain the ability to zoom out a bit with a costume.The game was a bit on the easy side.When loading/continuing a previous savestate the game doesn't tell you anything about the progress made. The game simply lists "Slot 1", "Slot 2" and "Slot 3". There isn't even an indication whether the slot actually contains any saved progress. This is a minor ugliness.I had a lot of fun with Costume Quest and Grubbins on Ice and highly recommend the game. I'm looking forward to playing the sequel.

Posted: September 25, 2015
												Usually when you think of a Halloween game, you think of a scary game, and those are all well and good; but what about a game that really brings the magic of Halloween itself? You know, costumes, trick or treating, having fun with your friends? Costume Quest somehow does it and does it very well. The first level already brims with nostalgia of days gone by (for me anyway) of walking the neighborhood at night and going door to door with a pale for the candy. You may wonder what the gameplay is like - well, first off the story is not serious, it's a light-hearted romp that'll make you smile for all ages. The overall story begins as your brother or sister (depending on who you choose to play as) gets kidnapped by strange monsters who love candy, and you are going to rescue them. The gameplay itself mostly is you going door to door in various places, and sometimes you get an adult with candy (which is like a currency in the game), or it could be a monster, which whom you have to fight.The fighting is done like a turn-based RPG, and you can get little things to help you out, called Battle Stamps. Each stamp has a unique ability you can use, each of your character gets one stamp per person, but you can switch them out if you don't care for it.There's no real dying in the game, you lose a battle, and you can just try again. The settings are really fun, like a neighborhood with various decorations, or a mall etc. The humor is really good, and adults and children will enjoy it, it's really a game for the family. Sadly, there's no co-op but it's fun on its own.There's also the DLC "Grubbins on Ice" included which adds 1-2 hours more. The core game isn't TOO long even getting everything, maybe 4-5 hours? But it's a lot of fun, and if you want to feel that Halloween nostalgia, this is the perfect game for you! The sequel is also very good, and worth checking out if you like the first one.

Posted: June 29, 2015
												I recommend this game to certain types of gamers.  It's very charming and sweet, but it is a little formulaic and tightly scripted and linear.  As someone who only started playing video games again a year or two ago, this is really in my wheelhouse and I can totally see others would find it somewhat tedious.  It's a pretty standard but minimal RPG: every encounter is planned, there are no truly random encounters, there is no way to grind and there are few real choices, except finding out what costumes and battle stamps work best together.  But there are all kinds of neat stuff, such as the trick-or-treating aspect and all the cute themed side quests like bobbing for apples and trading cards with other kids.  The dialogue and the whimsy are its strong suit.  I loved finding out what costumes would look like in battle and what their special abilities would be.  I personally loved the collecting candy aspect.  I could pail-bash as many garbage cans as they put in front of me!  After completing Grubbins on Ice, I highly recommend you play it after Costume Quest because I think the story works better that way.  I liked that environment especially.

Posted: June 22, 2015
												After trying Stacking and being disappointed, I wasn't sure if I'd like Costume Quest. Psychonauts was good - if not limited by platforming - and Costume Quest is right up there with it.The style is a charming, delightfully-quirky one that puts you in the role of a child on Halloween, trick or treating with their sibling. The pace spirals beautifully until you're facing off against giant monsters in a twisted maze, firing rockets.One of this game's seeling points is its fantastic humour; like Psychonauts it puts you in the position of a child and throws referential and meta humour at you, barrelling on whether you get the jokes or not. This is one of its strongest aspects as it's funny to those who get it and doesn't slow down those who don't.The combat is surprisingly deep considering the simple controls and is very balanced...except for the final boss in the extra adventure, Grubbins On Ice. The final boss of that doesn't follow the rules established in all the rest of the combat.Despite this little hiccough, it is a easy to grasp, QTE-based combat with scope for personal preference.One last thing to note is that it isn't very long; 9 hours to 100% it with all the achievements. There are shorter games out there and there are certainly longer games, but this is one of the funniest.
