Posted: April 29, 2015
												Costume Quest is an interesting RPG with a few minor flaws that keep it on just the wrong side of the greatness. Pros-Amazing Art Style, very cartoony and friendly.-Halloween Theme is awesome.-Manages to be appealing to kids but enjoyable for adults.Cons-A little too simple in certain areas. -Lack of combat and customization variety -Rediculous difficulty curve So firstly as I said the style is amazing, a lot of greens, oranges and blacks mix well to give the game a nostalgic feeling of halloween's past. You use different kids halloween costumes to have different powers and they change form between the overworld and the battles, both of which look great, almost cell shaded and comic like in places. The story is similarly charming and cartoon-like with a lot of effort put into appealing to the child in you and the nostalgia that part of you holds. I won't give out details but needles to say it is certainly interesting and although it doesn't take you to many 'new' places it will probably give you a fair few chuckles while playing it. However gameplay wise is were problems start to happen. It has solid enough combat, basically lifted directly from super mario RPG, with an extra damage/extra defence mechanic which has you playing very brief mini-games with each hit. Although the combat is solid it is also a little same-y, you'll find yourself doing the same thing over and over again but as you constantly get new costumes and abilites it doesn't really get boring. A big plus that helps remove some of the repetative nature of the game is a lack of grinding. Although you have to fight a certain number of fights in each area (sort of) you don't usually find yourself grinding to gain XP as you will rarley find yourself outstripped by enemies...until the ending. Okay so I'm not going to give the ending away or anything but between the last normal enemies you fight, groups of 3 level 10 enemes, and the final boss there is a 10 level difference. Meaning that although you can blitz through most of the game up until this point (completeing all quests is seriously not even a chore if you keep your eyes peeled) you will have to go back to previous areas to grind up at least 5 levels before you are even remotely ready to take on the final fight. This isn't helped by the final boss' ability to clone itself into 3, although that is the least of the issues. One final annoying point is that the ability to hold a button to go fast in the overworld is tied to a specific costume which means your main character has to wear it the entire game if you want to be able to move with any decent amount of speed, a very poor decision. Overall not a bad game, a little short and a huuuuuge difficulty/grin wall right at the very end but it has a lot of charm and if you can get past the issues you will find a great little experience. Worth picking up for such a low price and sure to be someones nostalgic memory in the future. 8/10

												Costume Quest plays like an introductory JRPG: classes are mapped onto interchangeable costumes that are unlocked by finding materials in the environment, equipment comes in the form of 'battle stamps' that can be purchased from vendors, and there are no consumables or 'game over' moments. Combat is simple and turn-based, but made slightly more interesting by requiring the player to press a random button at a given time to maximize or mitigate damage.It's a Doublefine game, so humor is a big part of the presentation. It's suitable for younger players, though some of the jabs at consumer culture and common RPG schticks will probably go over their heads.Between CQ and its (included) DLC, there's roughly eight hours of content.

												NOTE: For review with screenshots, please visit http://microfloppy.net/2014/08/12/costume-quest/Costume Quest is an adventure game by Double Fine Productions. It takes place during Halloween and you are either a twin sister or a twin brother who has to save your sibling from evil trolls.Unfortunately, when you start the game you can instantly tell that it's made for console. I gave it two minutes of wobbly movement using my arrow keys until I gave up and plugged in the Xbox-controller. You can also tell from the gameplay that this is a definite console game. One part of the game is basically to smash as many objects as possible and to solve easy quests to collect candy, the currency used in game. (And, for me, that becomes hopelessly monotonous.)The other part is to fight enemies, which is done with a classic turn-based fighting system. There's quick-time events here and you have to be fast on your xyab-buttons to get bonuses when you fight. (Something that also enhances the feeling of this being a console game.)In the end I can summarize the experience with saying that the graphics and the story gives some charm to the game, but that the gameplay becomes repetative. On the other hand, with an Xbox-controller, it would work great as some casual entertainment on a sickday or when you're a little hung over.Costume Quest will also be great if you can't get enough of collecting stuff in games. There's a long list of quests, achievements, halloween clothes, trading cards, and stamps that you can try to collect.4/10 candy corn

Posted: May 7, 2015
												Costume Quest is a game about capitalism and the futility of fighting the system. You play as Wren or Reynold, fraternal twins locked into a system in which happiness is always kept at arm's length. Your twin, the object of your worldly fulfillment, is taken from you, and you are forced to incorporate yourself into the capitalist consumer machine in order to free them from bondage - i.e. willfully enslaving yourself even deeper in order to cast off perceived oppression. The erstwhile heroes are indoctrinated into consumerism through perceived need. Costumes and battle stamps are tools by which they can defeat their perceived oppressors, and candy and creepy treats are the currency by which they can obtain them. The creepy treats only award a special costume upon completing a full set, forcing the consumer-hero to seek out other members of their in-group to trade with and developing a reliance upon victimizing the out-group in order to obtain more. The same is true for candy, but on a much larger scale: widescale destruction and abuse of natural resources is encouraged, and upon reentering a zone the supply magically replenishes itself. Candy is ultimately spent on battle stamps, an entirely extraneous commodity that the game can be won without, but is marketed as invaluable and a means by which to constantly sink the children's personal supply of wealth.The true capitalist hero of this story is Sadie, a brave young entrepeneur with a monopoly on the battle stamps market who is happy to aid the heroes in their fight against the villainous 'monsters.' She allows her customers to develop a dependence upon her product before beginning to dramatically ramp up the price to obtain newer and better versions of the same - designed obselescence at its finest. By the end of the game the player is lucky if they have several hundred pieces of candy in their bucket, while Sadie sits on thousands that the player spent to constantly upgrade their battle stamps. The 'monsters' of the game are cast as villains bent on hoarding all the world's candy for themselves, when in reality they are collecting it in order to save their own lives. Sadie, on the other hand, is motivated purely by profit - lying, expanding, and price-gouging to drive it ever higher.The harsh reality is that this game is designed to indoctrinate the player into heedlessly reaping the world's resources and victimizing their competition in the name of achieving fulfillment. They are taught to at the same time fear and trust the two heads of the capitalist serpent, sybomically mirrored by the twin heads of the Doublefine logo: the Repugians, who are the face of foreign investments, and Sadie, the friendly face who is always there to help. 10/10 illuminati confirmed.

Posted: March 14, 2015
												Costume Quest is a child's fantasy turned into a real game. You follow the protagonists as they have to fight a menacing threat on Halloween and their costumes will help them. I will give a short explanation concerning several aspects of the game.Gameplay:The gameplay is pretty solid, though it can get repetitive after a while. Each costume brings with it a certain power or ability that can be used to get past certain obstacles (Such as entering a location, passing an object and more). This means that every new costume you unlock will be used, one way or the other, to acquire new adventures, enemies, candy and secrets.The combat is turn based, but it works. The idea behind it is simple. You have to press the attack button (E for keyboard) and then time the same button again at the right moment (A small bar appears) to gain an effective attack.  After you have attacked, the enemies will attack your group. Defense works the same. The enemy goes into slow-motion, you get a chance to press the right button to defend yourself. Succeed and you get less damage, fail and you get more damage. On the third turn of the battle you unlock your costume's special abilities. And last, but not least, you can augment your costumes to enhance your performance in battle or cause status effects to your enemies by battle stamps, which you can purchase. Candy is the currency in the game.Story:The story is simple, but fun. As I wrote at the beginning of this review, it's pretty much a child's fantasy turned into a game. You have to fight monsters, your Halloween costumes give you super powers and you get to save the world. There's not really much to tell in this part.Sound:Same as with the story, the music is simple, but it works. It's not the type of soundtrack that starts to get annoying after a while and it does give you the proper atmosphere for the game.Style:The game has a very colourful appearance and you'll see this in-game as well. From the small houses in the comfy neighbourhood to the big, shiny, blasting super costumes, everything just screams fantasy. Total:If you're looking for a fun game and you don't mind a bit of repetitive combat, a simple story with a rich fantasy style attached and you can miss a few bucks/ euros, then go ahead, you'll probably enjoy it. However, if you're looking for a game with engaging gameplay, a rich story, a good challenge, this game won't be for you.Personal:I recommend it, I liked it, finally got around to finish it shortly before writing this review. A thumbs up from me.

Posted: May 2, 2014
												Want to play a eastern style rpg but can't be having with all that spiky or multicoloured hair? Want an rpg with a sense of humour? Like Halloween?You, Sir, have very specific tastes. Thankfully Costume Quest ticks all those boxes.Costume Quest is by Double Fine, the company that brought Psychonauts, Brutal Legend, Stacking and, more recently, Broken Age. It's a pretty good lineage to come from.You play as one of a pair of siblings, the sister Wren or the brother Reynold. Whichever of the two, you choose the other will get kidnapped and it's your job to rescue them.Along the way you will collect companions, complete minor quests and collect items to construct other costumes. Why would you want to do that you may ask? Well, beside acquiring the achievement for doing so, it will also give you some more options for combat and exploring the game world.Each costume has abilities when you go into combat wearing them. They can roughly be divided into three types (though some will span multiple types); Offence, Support and finally Defence.As you complete quests and fight your characters will level up and gain Battle Stamps. These stamps add extra abilities or buff your characters and winning the game is near impossible without them.The combat is in the style of an eastern style rpg. Your enemies stand on one side of the screen, you on the other and you take turns attacking each other. You defend yourself through a QTE (quick time event), which if you press the correct button on time will lessen the damage taken. Basic attacks are similar to the defence, you wait  for the prompt to mash a button, wiggle a stick or or just press the right button at the right time and if your successful you'll be rewarded with a critical hit. As you fight your costumes special abilities will charge up (usually around the 3rd turn). These attacks don't have a QTE and, depending on the costume, do great damage with an added effect, heal or protect.Try as I might I can't really fault the game. It's a little short but it's not exactly breaking the bank when it comes to buying it. You could easily complete the game and it's DLC (complete with all achievements for those that care for them) in a weekend.I recommend this game very highly, it's asking price isn't even that high for what it provides you.

												Remember when you were a kid and you played pretend in a costume, especially around Halloween? Well in this game you really do become your costume to fight off monsters and save your twin sibling from an evil witch and her army of candy-stealing grubbins on Halloween Night.Cutesy and silly, but with some clever jokes and some really fun combat. You unlock new powers by making new costumes using found items. In an industry mostly dominated by gritty realistic shooter games, blood soaked sci-fi shooter games, and football its nice to see a company that goes against the norm.

Posted: December 14, 2013
												This game will make you feel like a child again. You play as a child whose sibling, dressed as candy, is kidnapped by gremlins who steal candy on Halloween for their gremlin overlord. You collect a series of costumes and candy to work your way towards your kidnapped sibling. During a tedious RPG-style battle system, you become a Power Rangers-style gigantic form of your costume, each with a unique ability. Using the powers of your costumes, you defeat the gremlins, collect the candy in the area, and move on to the next. The humor is charming. There are many childlike jokes told as you communicate with other trick-or-treaters, but not in a sense of immaturity; the jokes will make you laugh like a child, fully encompassing the character. If you're a fan of the way Nintendo makes you feel when playing their games, or any of Double Fine's other imaginative productions, this game is a definite pick-up.

Posted: August 20, 2014
												Costume Quest is a game that is both a lot of fun and incredibly gripping. This is the kind of game that wisks you away back to your childhood memories of roaming the neighborhood going door to door trick-or-treating and the whole adventure feels like the kind of 'adventures' I went on as a kid. The gameplay itself was also pretty interesting, despite most of it being completing quests and turn based battles. The ability to construct new costumes and gain different abilities in the overworld and the battle system was great. Plus I feel that some of the quest objective help reinforce the Halloween theme, as each part of the world has trick-or-treating at every house in the area, much how as a kid I made sure to hit up every house. My only real complaint is that the battle system can get a bit repetitive and it feels just a bit to easy to do well with, but other than that I had a great time playing Costume Quest. It took me a little over 5 hours to play through the main story, but I still have yet to play the "Grubbins on Ice" story, so I would have to say that this is one of the few games where I feel it is still worth it if you pay the full $10 for it.

												I've played a coupld Double FIne games and they have yet again made a well rounded game.The game itself is simple yet at the same time can be complex in its own right with the simple RPG elements. The combat for the most part boils down to timed button pressing and selecting the right Battle Stamp for each character(these are basically special stat boosters) and earning xp to level up and Candy as currency to buy Battle Stamps to use in combat.Graphics alone are what really help to sell the game since the art style is so quirky and unique that it suits the comical style of the game.As for story and characters its almost like Tim Shafer took the Peanuts comics and made his own twisted version of it(in a good way) but for the most part the story is VERY simple but you don't notice that because the characters are the selling point honestly.10/10 Overall it was a fun little game that you can beat in around 6 to 8 hours depending if you're a completionist or not and regardless if you're a little kid or a 30+ something adult you will enjoy this little game.

												All right, Costume Quest was a fun little game. To sum it up in three words: "Baby's First J-RPG"The strongest point of Costume Quest is the writing. The banter reminds me of old Cartoon Network shows like Powerpuff Girls and Dexter's Laboratory. It pretty much carried the game for me.The gameplay itself is familiar from Chrono Triggers and Final Fantasies. Turn-based hit point reduction. I don't see anyone who has played a turn-based game being challenged by the combat.But in the end, the game is clearly developed for children. And unlike most children's games, this one has intelligence and wit behind it. I would recommend this to people who would like to give their child or child-like entity an easy and painless foray into the wondrous world of turn-based games.

Posted: October 29, 2012
												This is a great little game by Double Fine, and when I say little, I really do mean little. It took me about 6.5 hours to beat the game, plus its free (on steam) continuation of the story, Grubbins on Ice. There will no doubt be another added on continuation of the game, sometime in the future.The combat system is very similar to Super Mario RPG's, in that you time a button press to both do extra damage to an enemy, and to take less damage from an enemy. But this also has the addition of Battle Stamps, which act as battle-enhancing items. Stuff like applying a poison DoT to an enemy, or recovering some hp after each round in combat.All in all, even though I bought this the day before it went 50% off for halloween, I am very glad with this purchase, and still have the next chapter to look forward to. Buy this game, especially while it is on sale.

Posted: January 1, 2014
												Costume Quest is an RPG about trick-or-treating. You control a group of kids tasked with defeating a small army of monsters led by an evil witch in order to retrieve whichever of the sibling protagonists you don't choose at the start.Did I mention that it's by Double Fine Productions? Because that would explain that previous paragraph, for you.There's a weird division in imagination and reality in this game. The monsters are real. The plight is real. There's actually a witch ordering giant crows to steal candy to further her mysterious plans. But then once you enter battle, it becomes imaginary. I believe. I could certainly be wrong, but nobody else seems to notice when the heroes transform into colossal and more impressive versions of the things they're wearing costumes of. Even the monsters look much less doofy once battle commences. This all brings up an interesting point to consider, though, which is what the final boss looks like in reality - it's only ever seen in battle, you see (Grubbins on Ice notwithstanding, as that doesn't seem as married to this rule as the main game).Gameplay mostly consists of exploring, collecting, and fighting. You'll be searching every nook and cranny for various items to complete various quests, as well as to further the plot. Battles are launched by knocking on doors for candy (and later by encountering roaming monsters, as well), and abide by a turn-based system which encourages timed button presses, a la Mario RPG. There are also, notably, a limited number of battles (except maybe in the upper floors of the mall), so you're not expected to sit around and grind levels for hours to proceed.Different costumes give the kids different powers. Outside of battle, they're useful for overcoming obstacles or completing objectives. But inside battle, costumes are essentially classes. The robot is all attack, while the knight can defend himself or his teammates. Lady Liberty can heal the entire team partially, but the unicorn can heal one person to 100% HP.Movement is kind of odd, at first. If you point in a direction, your kid swivels in place to face that direction before setting off. Once in motion, you can make smooth turns, but pointing in the opposite direction will cause them to stop, turn, and then go. You get used to it by the second area, but it'll feel pretty wonky at first.The console releases of Costume Quest eventually received the paid DLC "Grubbins on Ice". You'll be pleased to hear that the DLC is now included at no additional charge! This bonus Winter-themed adventure sends the kids to the Grubbins' home... world? Dimension? Something. There are new costumes, stamps, and abilities to be found, and new monster types to fight. It's a quality addition, and worth the attention once the main game is complete.Costume Quest has become something of a Halloween tradition for me now. It's just short enough to invite such replayability. There are three major areas in the main game, and one more in Grubbins on Ice. Each one will likely take about two or three hours to complete, giving the game an 8-12 hour length for each playthrough. Just perfect for a run-through once every October, and the perfect game for the holiday. Costume Quest captures the spirit and imagination of trick-or-treating spendidly. Which suits me fine. I'm too old to go out trick or treating, anymore, but you're never too old to fight monsters in your underwear at 2 in the morning.

												This has become my wife's favorite video game of all time, giving a new meaning to Halloween.  Gameplay is simple, with just a few mechanics that are repeated almost to the point of boredom, but the story is what really sells the game. Posted: October 11, 2014
												Recommended because it's one of the funniest games ever. Unfortunately, it also has one of the worst battle systems ever. Although you can change costumes (effectively classes) outside of battle, once one starts you're stuck with what you went in wearing. And that's where the problem begins. Each class only has one attack and a timed special ability, none of which are particularly interesting. Worse, because there are only two costumes in the game with healing abilities, every battle had to be designed around the possibility that the player would be totally unable to heal. The end result is that every battle is exactly the same thing whether you're fighting a boss or a basic encounter. They tried to add a bit of variation with equippable Battle Stamps. Unfortunately, you're limited to one per character, can't change in battle, and some of them are objectively better than others. They don't solve the problem. If you're willing to put up with the awful battles for fantastic writing and some unique scenarios, it's worth the sale price of $5. I'd struggle to recommend it at much higher of a price, unfortunately, because this is a game that hits its peak early. It's a fantastic first 90 minutes, a pretty good second 90 minutes, and a third that I didn't finish because it had become primarily battles rather than laughs. Minor note: This game has terrible mouse acceleration that can't be turned off. It doesn't affect gameplay at all, but it makes menu navigation annoying.

Posted: November 26, 2014
												Tell me, you ever play a game called Paper Mario? Well, this game is kinda like that, only instead of playing as a plumber in a world made out of paper, you play a child during Halloween with an overactive imagination.. Or, is it in his/her mind? I suppose that is a mystery for yourself to solve.Costume Quest is a charming, yet sadly short, turn-based RPG with an amusing story about two siblings who used to bicker with each other on a daily basis.. Until one of  them gets kidnapped, leading the other on a quest to get their sibling back, and in the process making new friends as well as learning to get along with the sibling they once disliked. As I said, the game is kinda like Paper Mario, where there are no random battles, and combat is based on timing button presses to get the highest damage as well as reduce incoming damage. What makes it different is the game's main gimmic: Costumes.There is a decent selection of outfits one can aquire throughout the game, some earned during the story, others by completing optional quests. Depending on the costume you and your friends wear, it'll affect how fights play out. The costume YOU wear is also important, because some outfits have abilities that'll allow you to progress or make your game easier (Such as lighting up dark paths or sneaking around in plain sight).Of course, this game isn't just about costumes, but also trick or treating. In each chapter, you will be required to do some trick or treating in order to unlock gates. This is a rather amusing system, because behind each door lies a, of course, a trick or treat. If it is a treat, you get some free candy, which can be used to buy upgrades and abilites that can allow you to customise your style of play beyond just what costume you prefer to main. However, if you stumble across a trick, you get tossed into a simple battle. Anyone who played Paper Mario probably has a good idea how these battles work for the most part. They are quite fun, but after awhile it does get repetitive due to the simple combat system. Doesn't mean it is boring, though, because some battles really are quite engaging (and in a few cases, really hard unless you make use of a certain outfit or stamp).At first, combat is challenging and thrilling, but as you progress in the game, it does start to get a bit anti-climatic (At least, until near the end), where you are able to effortlessly mow down anyone who crosses your path. Doesn't help that the highest you can level is up to 10, which brings up another sad thing about this game: It is short....At first, the game will seem quite epic, your expectations probably being that it'll be a decently sized venture.. But then you reach level 10, and discover that you cannot level any further.. it is at that point that you discover that the end is near, and when I discovered this, I was a bit disappointed... I had gotten so invested that I was sad my adventure was almost over. At least the game ended with a bang, and I liked that, but it left me wanting more. Thankfully, there is a bonus adventure for those willing to brave it that are not totally satisfied.Is this game worth checking out? I'd say so. Despite its flaws, it is a charming title that I am glad I had the pleasure to experience, even if it was a short one.

												COSTUME QUEST: THIS LOOKS GREAT, PLAYS GREAT IS FUN ALL ROUND AND A TRICK OR TREAT TO PLAY! EXCELLENT GAME AND IDEAL FOR ADULTS WHO WANT TO PLAY SOMETHING WITH THEIR KIDS. A MUST FAMILY FAVOURITE! CANT WAIT TO TRY COSTUME QUEST 2.

Posted: March 14, 2015
												Costume Quest is a child's fantasy turned into a real game. You follow the protagonists as they have to fight a menacing threat on Halloween and their costumes will help them. I will give a short explanation concerning several aspects of the game.Gameplay:The gameplay is pretty solid, though it can get repetitive after a while. Each costume brings with it a certain power or ability that can be used to get past certain obstacles (Such as entering a location, passing an object and more). This means that every new costume you unlock will be used, one way or the other, to acquire new adventures, enemies, candy and secrets.The combat is turn based, but it works. The idea behind it is simple. You have to press the attack button (E for keyboard) and then time the same button again at the right moment (A small bar appears) to gain an effective attack.  After you have attacked, the enemies will attack your group. Defense works the same. The enemy goes into slow-motion, you get a chance to press the right button to defend yourself. Succeed and you get less damage, fail and you get more damage. On the third turn of the battle you unlock your costume's special abilities. And last, but not least, you can augment your costumes to enhance your performance in battle or cause status effects to your enemies by battle stamps, which you can purchase. Candy is the currency in the game.Story:The story is simple, but fun. As I wrote at the beginning of this review, it's pretty much a child's fantasy turned into a game. You have to fight monsters, your Halloween costumes give you super powers and you get to save the world. There's not really much to tell in this part.Sound:Same as with the story, the music is simple, but it works. It's not the type of soundtrack that starts to get annoying after a while and it does give you the proper atmosphere for the game.Style:The game has a very colourful appearance and you'll see this in-game as well. From the small houses in the comfy neighbourhood to the big, shiny, blasting super costumes, everything just screams fantasy. Total:If you're looking for a fun game and you don't mind a bit of repetitive combat, a simple story with a rich fantasy style attached and you can miss a few bucks/ euros, then go ahead, you'll probably enjoy it. However, if you're looking for a game with engaging gameplay, a rich story, a good challenge, this game won't be for you.Personal:I recommend it, I liked it, finally got around to finish it shortly before writing this review. A thumbs up from me.

												One really great achievement of Costume Quest is the combination of childhood fantasy stories filled with knights, robots, pirates and such ; the classical gameplay of japanese adventure rpg and the whole spiced-up with humor.Sure the game might seem short for a grown-up, even too easy or too linear, but that's the kind of game I'd have loved to play when I was a child and one of the most enjoyable I've played recently. Posted: December 14, 2014
												halloween-themed rpg with simple turn-based combat. gave me billy and mandy vibes at times. felt like an rpg for kids with its simple quests and directions, but i love halloween too much to feel any shame. not that i don't think adults won't enjoy this.the story doesn't take itself seriously and was good enough to make me want to find out what happens next, the funny dialogue and cute cartoon artstyle mix well to create a comfortable halloween feel.the combat has quick-time events for offense and defense. classes (attack, defense, support, and special) are determined by the costume the character wears. costumes are changeable and each has its own stats (health and attack) and unique special attack that is charged every 3 turns. there are also equipable "battle stamps" that modify health and attack. the battle stamps can also give a unique ability such as resurrection, poison, or dodge chance. the combat was easy enough to where i rarely felt the threat of defeat. the camera is impressively cinematic in battle with pans, zooms, and letterboxing.gameplay outside of combat has literal trick-or-treating, fetch quests, bobbing for apples, playing hide-and-seek, defeating specific enemies, and doing-this-to-be-able-to-go-there's to progress in the story and collect items. some costumes have an ability outside of combat that allow you to access otherwise inaccessible areas. the dialogue and atmosphere keep the overworld entertaining despite the simplicity. there is a quest log to help you keep track, but there is no map. however, the areas were not so complex to where i felt lost.there are three levels that you can teleport between, so don't worry about missables. you also can't jump. this is frustrating when something you want to get is just out of reach, but look around enough and you will find a way to get to it.

Posted: November 8, 2014
												This was sort of a "Child's First RPG". There are attack, magic and support costumes that you can choose from as you work your way around Halloween in the American suburbs to defeat the candy-stealing monsters and their witch boss. It is ridiculously easy - there is no challenge to the turn-based combat as long as you take out the healers first - but I still enjoyed the two evenings I spent finishing this game and the add-on. If you're looking for something serious, this probably isn't what you want, but it has some fantastic charm in both the world-creation and the writing. Also the magic fry-crab/spider thing is pretty hilarious. I played as that for ages.Edit - I got this game a long time ago, but found playing with a keyboard completely unworkable. A controller made the game playable.

Posted: December 11, 2014
												For me, Costume Quest is the archetypal current Double Fine game. It has a great idea, nice presentation, and tedious, repetitive gameplay where you do the same thing over and over again until the designers thought it was long enough to satisfy the minimum game length people want. SomehowCostume Quest manages to distill and concentrate the absolute worst elements of JRPG design into a seemingly endless grind mitigated a little by the cute plot and presentation.The basic idea is that you have a Final Fantasy style RPG where the protagonists are children on haloween and classes are replaced by costumes, each with their own special abilities. This is, on the face of it, a brilliant idea. The problem is the game consist mostly of combat, and you are actually required to fight most of the enemies in order to proceed, against a small number of enemies, using a tiny number of attacks that you use over and over again. Worse, the attacks also incorporate a timing minigame, so you can't even get through the grind it by hammering the attack button while you read a book or something, because you have to pay attention to the events in the game in order to get the timing right.

It's more fun that way, in my opinion.Also, you get to go trick-or-treating. I can relive my childhood every time I play, lol.The concept is fun too. Being able to try different costumes is a cool idea, and watching them transform into incredible heroes is quite entertaining. 11/10 woot

Posted: January 1, 2014
												Costume Quest is an RPG about trick-or-treating. You control a group of kids tasked with defeating a small army of monsters led by an evil witch in order to retrieve whichever of the sibling protagonists you don't choose at the start.Did I mention that it's by Double Fine Productions? Because that would explain that previous paragraph, for you.There's a weird division in imagination and reality in this game. The monsters are real. The plight is real. There's actually a witch ordering giant crows to steal candy to further her mysterious plans. But then once you enter battle, it becomes imaginary. I believe. I could certainly be wrong, but nobody else seems to notice when the heroes transform into colossal and more impressive versions of the things they're wearing costumes of. Even the monsters look much less doofy once battle commences. This all brings up an interesting point to consider, though, which is what the final boss looks like in reality - it's only ever seen in battle, you see (Grubbins on Ice notwithstanding, as that doesn't seem as married to this rule as the main game).Gameplay mostly consists of exploring, collecting, and fighting. You'll be searching every nook and cranny for various items to complete various quests, as well as to further the plot. Battles are launched by knocking on doors for candy (and later by encountering roaming monsters, as well), and abide by a turn-based system which encourages timed button presses, a la Mario RPG. There are also, notably, a limited number of battles (except maybe in the upper floors of the mall), so you're not expected to sit around and grind levels for hours to proceed.Different costumes give the kids different powers. Outside of battle, they're useful for overcoming obstacles or completing objectives. But inside battle, costumes are essentially classes. The robot is all attack, while the knight can defend himself or his teammates. Lady Liberty can heal the entire team partially, but the unicorn can heal one person to 100% HP.Movement is kind of odd, at first. If you point in a direction, your kid swivels in place to face that direction before setting off. Once in motion, you can make smooth turns, but pointing in the opposite direction will cause them to stop, turn, and then go. You get used to it by the second area, but it'll feel pretty wonky at first.The console releases of Costume Quest eventually received the paid DLC "Grubbins on Ice". You'll be pleased to hear that the DLC is now included at no additional charge! This bonus Winter-themed adventure sends the kids to the Grubbins' home... world? Dimension? Something. There are new costumes, stamps, and abilities to be found, and new monster types to fight. It's a quality addition, and worth the attention once the main game is complete.Costume Quest has become something of a Halloween tradition for me now. It's just short enough to invite such replayability. There are three major areas in the main game, and one more in Grubbins on Ice. Each one will likely take about two or three hours to complete, giving the game an 8-12 hour length for each playthrough. Just perfect for a run-through once every October, and the perfect game for the holiday. Costume Quest captures the spirit and imagination of trick-or-treating spendidly. Which suits me fine. I'm too old to go out trick or treating, anymore, but you're never too old to fight monsters in your underwear at 2 in the morning.

												Great game if you have a little time on your hands.  It streamlines the RPG experience with a simpler exploration feel that keeps the user involved until the end.  The biggest drawbacks are the repetive, three button combat and length.  Sadly, you can 100% this game in less than 8 hours if you care to. Posted: May 19, 2013
												A simple, yet very fun RPG made by Double Fine Productions. Not very surprising, since the company is known for making pretty fun games. Costume Quest uses a simple turn-based RPG battle system, so there isn't really any kind of learning curve to it. The story is pretty simple and not deep, but the characters are likeable. The costumes you wear decide what you fight as and what attack and special ability you have. It can be pretty fun to mess around and decide what the best team to use is. The game isn't really hard, but if you don't have a good team set up, it can be easy to lose. Even if you lose, there is no penalty or anything of that sort, which is sort of nice. If your a fan of simple turn-based RPGs, I fully recommend you try this game. (Note: If you aren't very good with quick time events using keyboard butons, I fully recommend you use a controller, preferably an Xbox 360 controller.)

Posted: September 24, 2014
												This game brings back the feeling of childhood wonder like few games can. Mechanically, half of Costume Quest falls firmly into the JRPG genre with a very simple battle system and overworld exploration where you open chests and talk to people and fight monsters and bosses.The other half is basically an adventure game. Each costume your kids can wear has its own abilities both in and out of combat, and the non-combat abilities will be crucial to solving the environmental puzzles your team will run into throughout the game.Both halves of the game are excellent and easy to learn, and the magic of Halloween is fully preserved in the game's environments and presentation. Play it!

												This video game inspired me. I was once the empty shell of a woman you see in my profile picture, but the light and childish motifs of this videogame has awakened me to a new philosphy of life in this late capitalist society. The rapid switching of costumes spoke to me. BE FREE! LIVE YOUR MOST AUSPICIOUS REALITIY! If you want to be a robot BE A ROBOT! Just go for it! Take off your shirt! Lather yourself in auto oil and coolant. Install factory standard wiring between your nerves and muscles! MAKE YOURSELF INTO THE BEST YOU YOU CAN BE! My daughter, Nancy, once said to me, Mom, you're spending far too much of the money from the college fund for all these body modifications and Costume Quest™ brand costume pices. She seems to think that I ought be spending my money on Goobles on Ice™ merchandise, but this game teaches me the same thing so I told her I am her mother and I brought her into the world I can take her out LOL !!Great game, my only complaint is that you can't design your own characters. 8/10.

Posted: October 18, 2015
												For a game designed for younger players in mind, I still found this rather enjoyable to play. The combat is rather simplistic, but still felt challenging in some of the boss fights. For most fights, chain-stunning the foes turned out to be the most effective play to buy time to build up your costume special attacks. The story is rather predictable, and the quests are more  or less repeated in each location, but it didn't seem to be that much of a turn-off as it should have been. For the price of the game, I really felt like I got a good deal of value from the game, considering the 'Grubbins On Ice' DLC that comes with the game is effectively another few hours of content that expands the story of the game (or can be a hard-mode if you just start it w/o using a save that had main game data). I'd recommend it to anyone that wants to play a fairly easy RPG to kill a few hours between more serious RPGs.

Posted: October 16, 2015
												I don't know about other people, but I think Halloween got me more excited than any other holiday, even Christmas. There was something fun about "being" something else for a night. Also, the pails full of candy. Double Fine does a wonderful job portraying the things I loved about Halloween as a kid while also giving me things to appreciate as an adult.The art direction is top notch. There is a very consistant design aesthetic that carries through the entire game, one that would look right at home as part of a Halloween cartoon special. The character design eschews realism for expressiveness - not quite to the completely distended extremes of Psychonauts, but still not aiming for "realism". The main characters are kind of chibi, which is great because it allows for a remarkable expressiveness. Par for the course in a Double Fine title, the dialogue (all written, no voice acting) is really sharp and loaded with humor both obvious and subtle. The background music tends to be fairly repetitive, but it's atmospheric and compliments the visual design. Shades of Danny Elfman, which is a *perfect* choice for Halloween.The game itself is a turn-based RPG but with active, timing based offense and defense boosts. It's very similar to Super Mario RPG (which, if it didn't innovate that style definitely codified it) in how it plays out. Actually, of any game to compare the gameplay to, I'd compare it to Hothead's Penny Arcade Adventures. It's funny, Ron Gilbert came over from Hothead just a month before the game was released - he didn't actually have any direct impact on the game, but given Tim Schafer and Ron Gilbert's long-term association, I can't but help think he cribbed from his friend's design. Which is fine because it worked then and it worked in this game. Add in a dash of Earthbound, in being able to engage with enemies on screen before the turn-based battle begins, and you've got a tried-and-true formula.The costume transformations are fun and the special powers associated with the costumes are anywhere from "useful" to "hilarious", in the case of the Lady Liberty costume. One thing the game could be dinged on is a lack of variance in combat. There's only one special power per costume, and a handful of optional "third powers" that can be added. In actual practice, a lot of combat could be completed by just attacking, waiting for the special attack to power up, unleash the attack and if anything is still standing repeat the process. The combat is thankfully fast-paced for a turned-based RPG, but it can get somewhat repetitive.I could harp on a few other things. The game is short - even if you explore and find everything, expect 5-6 hours at most if you're able to win most battles (and you probably will). Of course, as an adult with a job, short isn't a crime for me, but those who hear RPG and expect 99 hours of playtime will be sorely disappointed. The story is simple, which fits a game about a bunch of kids on Halloween night turning into their costumes and saving their sibling and their candy stashes, but there could have been a little bit more meat on the story's bones. Characterization was strong and it goes a long way, but the world of Costume Quest is charming enough that I felt like I was missing something to not get more. The environmental "puzzles" are barely a challenge and the solutions are nearly flat out stated by some NPCs who might as well add "GET IT?" to their obvious, pun-based solutions. Then again, it's a great entry level title for children. For adults, you'll probably find the puzzles and their solutions too, too easy.But those are quibbles. Costume Quest is one of the most charming games I've played. It's got a great atmosphere and  great idea for a game that ends before the shtick gets old. The game also, I might add, is fairly diverse in its characterization and does not limit costumes amongs the PCs by gender. Yes, Double Fine, I noticed, and it's an awesome thing to see game designers implement.I definitely recommend this game to people tired of gray-and-gritty, guns-and-guts gaming. The game will make you smile. It's no challenge at all, if that's how you want to measure "worth" in a game, but the wit of the game and the clever concept will make the game worth the price of admission in my opinion. It's a perfect compliment to the season and if you have even the barest interest in RPGs - or have never played one before and want one to try that isn't going to overwhelm you with entirely new gaming concepts - you'll enjoy the game. And just like Halloween candy, don't rush the experience. Savor it instead of gobbling it all down at once. I get the temptation, but you'll just get a tummy ache if you do!

Posted: July 9, 2014
												When two twins end up getting separated on a Halloween night due to a mysterious invasion of candy-hogging trolls and their wicked witch leader, it is up to you to reunite them on a well spirited RPG-style adventure harnessing the power of vastly varied classic Halloween costumes!The story has a cute enough heart to it as it is, but I feel the short length left out *a lot* of potential such as more character development, also with the theme of Halloween and the obvious influence of Nintendo's Mother/Earthbound-titles, I couldn't help but feel like the tale could've been spicier with a little more daring, genuinely frightening moments. The all around atmosphere still holds up well in the graphics, cute character design and the fitting soundtrack.The costumes were fun, in both putting together via finding the necessary items and just plain seeing them in action during the turn-based battles, their own limit-attacks especially! When not fighting you spend your time searching for either candy, treasure-coffins, sidequests or the occasional minigame, all of which are also classic RPG features and were splendidly Halloween themed, but even during such short run some of them began feeling a bit repetitive. Trick-or-treating around the field was an exciting way to either treat yourself to most of your candy or get tricked into an enemy encounter!All in all it doesn't take too much (or enough, more fittingly) of your time and is slightly flawed, but still had me and will surely have any other RPG and Halloween lover invested all the way!

Posted: January 16, 2012
												A cutesy, simplistic RPG?  Meh.  Tell me Tim Schafer's had a hand in development?  Well, as little of Psychonauts that I've played, that's an interesting factoid but doesn't sell me.  All the moves in battle have action commands a la Super Mario RPG?  Now I'm listening.This is an engaging game.  Cute, but Tim Schafer cute with adult overtones.  Like Psychonauts, the landscapes are built for exploration and look great.  Battles couldn't be any more basic, but the need to react to quick time-esque button presses to either boost attacks or minimize incoming damage keeps you on your toes.  Each costume you acquire is unique and works differently in battles, making it fun to experiment and find the perfect combination for your play style.  It's short, no more than six hours, but it's actually the perfect length.  Maybe it's not worth the full asking price, but if Costume Quest comes up in a Steam sale...  grab it.  And let candy gluttony take you on a fun little journey.

Posted: March 15, 2013
												Well Double Fine you made another good game, I applaude you. See Double Fine continues to make good games, something few companies can do, much like RareWare in the 1990's, Tim Schafer's Double Fine seems to be dishing out game after game of quality. He is of course well known to the people who have heard of him, but that is shockingly few people. His games like Grim Fandango, and Phychonauts are glimmering underappreciated diamonds, and his lastest game Costume Quest does nothing to tarnish that reputation.Now why do I compare Double Fine to Rare? Easy, they both made a multitude of games that made them very popular, Double Fines biggest issue is it is still the unknown company, thier games come out, they look cool to some people, I play them, love them, then I tell other people how good they are for just being 20 bucks or less, then no one plays them. But I hold no resentment towards those people because I grew up with with Tim at my side, a man that made good games, I do hope that someday I can say 'Hey, you know that game that everyone likes that just came out, try this it's made by the same guys.' Then we get people playing Double Fines old catalog of games.But about Costume Quest, it's good, it's charming, it has a few pop culture references, most don't seem out of place unless you know them. But the big thing is, it shows that Double Fine can make a decent Role Playing Game. Now don't get me wrong it's not as in depth as some major RPG's, but it does what you want it to do. There are no voices, just text, which is fine, the dialouge makes me chuckle, and brings out the little things in characters. It's just enough exploration, it is a little limiting, but it cuts down on annoying long term searches, and overall the game keeps at a fairly difficult stance. See it's these types of games that I like to see game companies make, they normally make puzzle games or platformers, but then they release an explore centered RPG and then it's actually good. That is what I like to see, I like to see companies improve and expand thier game base with more than platformers, because really I will lose intrest eventually, but it is safe to say Double Fine is keeping another fan interested and excited for the future.

Posted: April 8, 2014
												Alright, Costume Quest. Pretty charming. It is a JRPG set in a halloween theme. As it seems to be the usual thing about Double Fine productions, the artstyle and designs of pretty much everything in the whole thing is very good pretty and nice for the theme. That is very good. You gotta love Double Fine for that pattern by the way. The story is also funny and children friendly, no voice actors, so you have to read, which is not bad, except if you are foreign. However, it is a JRPG and that is a genre, that seriously is pretty old. Something not that good. They have to be congratulated however for not putting in linear corridors or random encounters, but the combat is still really simple, gets boring and gives not really any punishment for defeat. I wonder why they even put in a run away button. So the combat is pretty much just padding, but since Double Fine is, as far as I know, an indie game company, it can slide. It also has a lot of side quests and collectibles. Nothing for me, but you might enjoy it. The innovation is the costumes, which is easy to change between, and it gives a lot of different fighting styles and problem solving. The puzzles are however pretty much told how to solve, so no bonus there. In conclusion, Costume Quest is nothing ground breaking, but as someone who does not like mainstream JRPG it is alright. It will be the same for people who likes JRPG. It is like a little nice twix bar, that you eat fastly, and it is alright, but you will very soon forget it. If you have kids, buy this to them, because there are not that many good kid games, besides lego i suppose. If you want it for yourself, you can do a lot worse, but if you have not played Psychonauts, save the extra buck and buy that first, because it is a lot more ground breaking and creative.

Posted: October 28, 2016
												"Costume Quest" is a fine opportunity to get into the Halloween mood. Or even deeper.It is a one-player RPG game involving two twin siblings getting separated by candy-greedy monsters from Repugia and two friends of theirs. So one sibling gets kidnapped and the other three children (including you as the twin brother or sister) set off for the rescue while fighting monsters, bosses and having fun by collecting Halloween stuff (costumes, candy, candy cards, battle stamps) and solving quests that get in your way.The gameplay: Most of the time you will walk around places like your hometown or the town's mall and search for items and quests. All of these help you progress in the story and getting stronger. One quest you must complete a couple of times in order to progress is to knock on every available door to ask for treats. Either you just get them or have to battle a monster (that has occupied this house). So the other part of the game are the battles. The children use their costumes they've achieved (pumpkin, black cat, vampire, statue of liberty, etc...) and their special powers to fight the different monsters. And because it's an RPG you wait for your characters' turns and choose the actions they're suppoused to do now while the monsters get their turns, too. You can loose battles but never die. You just would have to try again. Every win is rewarded with experience points, candy and other items.During all this you have your note book with you in which you have an overlook of your status, quests (and their status), costumes (with description), candy cards and a variety of battle stamps which can be used for battle by your characters.I found "Costume Quest" very playable, the controls are easy to learn (and they're changeable if you really can't operate with them). I played with the keyboard and it worked just fine. It's a fun RPG with a good mixture of exploring, collecting and fighting. It's also easy to play, so also RPG beginners shouldn't have trouble to finish this game sooner or later.The cartoonish 2.5/3D graphics are mostly sweet and lovely designed, that goes especially for the settings you go to.  They're colourful but not rainbow puking bright, they mostly match the Halloween season. When it goes to the characters, I find the children, their battle characters and the monsters were designed okay. I can't say that about the adult characters who either look like obese puppets, lifeless big-nosed humans or stick figures with grotesque heads and faces. They don't only look strange but also quite lifeless. I wished that a bit more effort would have went into their designs. But to the game's credit: the adults play a very minor role compared to the children.The sound is so-so: I enjoyed the musical score very much. But the sound? It completely containts sound effects (which are fine), no voices (outside the occesional grunts of monster characters and human background mumbling in more crowded places). This means that the dialogues are all text bubbles and there are even no simple sounds expressed by the characters, wether a "Gasp!" or "Huh?" or "Ouch" or something. I find this negative since at least a bit of voice acting brings extra life to these characters but here, everybody is totally quiet. What about extras? There are achievements, trading cards, one minigame about apple bobbing and there is also an additional chapter included called "Grubbins on Ice" that goes on right after the story of the main game. I can't say it's that exciting or so much fun, you practically do the same things and collect new costumes but without Halloween going on. Still, it's worth for a bit of fun and the achievements.So, can I recommend "Costume Quest"? Yes, absolutely. It's a sweet, fun game all around Halloween and the fantasy of children celebrating it. If you can't stand Halloween or just don't care about it, then I guess this shouldn't stop you from trying but you might have less joy with that game.And if you're into RPGs or starting this, you definitely should check it out.

												For a game designed for younger players in mind, I still found this rather enjoyable to play. The combat is rather simplistic, but still felt challenging in some of the boss fights. For most fights, chain-stunning the foes turned out to be the most effective play to buy time to build up your costume special attacks. The story is rather predictable, and the quests are more  or less repeated in each location, but it didn't seem to be that much of a turn-off as it should have been. For the price of the game, I really felt like I got a good deal of value from the game, considering the 'Grubbins On Ice' DLC that comes with the game is effectively another few hours of content that expands the story of the game (or can be a hard-mode if you just start it w/o using a save that had main game data). I'd recommend it to anyone that wants to play a fairly easy RPG to kill a few hours between more serious RPGs.

Posted: December 5, 2015
  What better way to spend a few hours than pummeling monsters as a giant rainbow unicorn?  Costume Quest is a fun, youthful, and humorous adventure that utilizes overworld exploration, puzzle solving, and a simple turn-based combat system. I would recomend it to children, people looking for a not-scary halloween game, and anyone who would like to nostagically relearn some of the magic of halloween.This game does a lot of things well and a few things not so well. Good Stuff:  Concept  - I love the sheer idea of this game. A group of kids must use their costumes that ACTUALLY TRANSFORM THE WEARERS to fight monsters, save a sibling, and collect tons of candy along the way. It sounds like all of my childhood halloween fantasies at once. Story  - Less predicatable than one might image. It has just enough twists to keep it interesting, but manages to keep it simple enough for a younger person to enjoy it. Characters  - Likeable child characters are comparable to black republicans nowadays: maybe there's one or two here and there, but overall they're pretty rare. The children in this game are highly likeable and funny, which is a metaphorical breath of fresh air. Humour  - My inner 10 year old got a real kick out of this game. The jokes are silly and childish, but I'd be lying if I said I didn't laugh quite a bit during my playthrough. I wish more games could imbue such a good sense of humour into their games. Stuff That Was Ok:  Music  - It wasn't exactly a synphonic masterpiece, but it does add to the immersion. My only qualm is that the battle music can get a bit repettitive. World/Map  - Again, it wasn't mind blowing or pioneering or anything like that. Each area is pretty different, which does well to break up any monotony. Some environmental objects (specifically, ramps) can feel really clunky, but all-in-all it doesn't affect the enjoyment of the game. Stuff I Wish Was Different:  Character Progression  - I believe that the Devs wanted to create a simple RPG that was less about combat and leveling up and more about the story. They absolutely succeeded, so props to them. I do wish that there would have been a slightly more in-depth character upgrade system, but that's just me. Combat  - Like I said above, the game isn't really combat or skill focused. The combat is simple and easy to learn, which is good. The problem with simple combat is that it can get very, very repetitive. I was actually somewhat sad when the thought "ugh, do I really have to fight these guys?" came to mind, because to me it meant that the combat had gotten boring. It's worth noting that I was admittedly about 3/4 of the way through before that happened. Lighting  - My last minor complaint is the lighting in the game. For the majority of the game, the Devs did a great job of keeping the overall lighting pretty low, but bright enough to see where you were going and to find the things you needed to find. However, the  first part of the 2nd act and the upper two floors of the mall area  are just too dark. There is a brightness option in the menu, but amping up the brightness seems almost to be cheating, since part of the game's charm is the comic-spookiness of low lighting. That's really my only complaint on the world design. Final Summation:   I really did enjoy this game. It was a fun way to spend a few hours, and it made me think back to my childhood dreams about being the costume I wore on halloween. Would recommend.

Posted: December 30, 2015
												Not badStoryYou are a kid that goes Trick and Treating with their sibling who is swiftly kidnapped by monsters. Now it is your job to go door to door trick or treating, complete quests, and fight monsters. It’s pretty much a standard RPG with a halloween theme painted on it. The story isn’t bad and it follows Double Fine’s formula well (kid looking game with often adult adventures that is eccentric). There are some dark elements to the game which come out really well and the whole game has a theme of child wonder to it. You fight as real transformers, unicorns, and vampires while facing daemons. It sounds like a kid fantasy. However, the story isn’t flushed out as Psychonauts for example and I don't really remember muchGameplayIt’s a standard RPG (with a twist). The main point is to go around to all of the stores/houses and trick or treat. Different areas are blocked out until you can unlock certain areas. This is mostly done through monster fights. Overall, this system is nice as it moves the plot along via your actions but gets very repetitive near the end as you just end up going from monster fight to monster fight. Speaking of which, the monster battles are a bit simple. You can have up to 3 characters each of which has a regular move and a special ability with a long cool down. Additionally, you have different patches you can apply which are absolutely necessary to stand a chance. It took me a while to find a pair that worked for me but in the end, it was all just the same thing over and over until the end. Overall, I found the system a bit simple and I don’t play RPGs muchPerformance:With a 4790k, GTX 970, and 16GB of ram, it ran at either 30 or 60fps for me. It didn’t vary in between those two numbers but rather certain scenes and areas were stuck at 30. The game isn’t aiming to be realistic so the graphics are cartoony.Overall, the game was OK. I’m reminded of South Park: The Stick of Truth a lot and honestly, I would recommend playing that over this game. It’s not bad but just kinda meh to above meh.

												I went in expecting (and hoping) Costume Quest would be a "light" RPG. Most RPGs leave me dreading them, honestly. 40 hours of game play for 2 hours of storyline. Tons of meaningless sidequests. Mass amounts of combat, leaving you feeling more like a mass-murdering psychopath than the hero of any book or movie.Costume Quest sounded "light" in all the ways I was looking for: doesn't try for an "epic" 40-hour plot, doesn't have thousands of items and customisations, doesn't have hundreds of sidequests.After a few hours of play, I just found the game (especially combat) to be too repetitive.Only 38% of players have even bothered to beat the first boss in the game. Only 27% stick around to the second boss. I get the feeling that most people think this is a neat idea and a cute looking game but don't stick around for very long.

Posted: January 7, 2016
												One word to describe the whole game : CUTEJust finished literally a few minutes ago and I LOVED every second of it.Costume Quest is an adorable game about kids on adventure in their Halloween costumes which give them super powers. This is the dream of every little kid (and grown ups) that ever played make-believe. Plot : really straight-forward. Team up with the neighborhood kids to save your sibling. A classic good vs evil in a comedic way. Grubbin on Ice is like a mini-sequel or a spin-off and it's highly recommended to play it AFTER the main CQ.Gameplay : I highly recommend using a controller. I can't imagine the battle sequences using a keyboard and mouse, but if you're comfortable with them then maybe it'll work for you. The walking around was a bit tiresome, but worth it.Quests : all the quests are really well-thought, and a good way to grind, though you can't get past level 10 for the main CQ and not past level 14 for GOI. Puzzles : it's not as frustrating, as long as you're EXTREMELY thorough in searching and walking around.Graphic : I love the character designs, the monsters, the battle sequences.. The backgorunds are pretty smooth. I didn't enjoy the dark areas, but I generally don't like dark areas in game anyway so I guess it's a matter of preference.Sound : it's fun and adds up to the atmosphere of going on an adventure.Characters : I really like how all the characters have names, even the NPCs (though not the monsters). The enemies are not EVIL evil, and as lovable as the protagonists.I give this as 10/10. Just need one more achievement to fill but that'll have to wait.. literally..MOVING ON TO CQ2 !!!

Posted: January 9, 2016
												I'm a dork when it comes to Halloween and all things spooky so if you're like me, you will enjoy this game. It's so nostalgic, it makes me miss trick-or-treating and wish I saw it through these characters' eyes. The costumes are fun to use and have unique abilities, the dialogue is hilarious, and the story is well-thought out. I'm a little upset by how the short game was, but mostly because I was having so much fun and I didn't want it to end. But there are a lot of extra things to finish so I'm looking forward to it.

Posted: January 8, 2016
												As a fan of Double Fine's earlier efforts, especially Psychonauts, it's no surprise Costume Quest drew my attention with little effort. Given I'm also a fan of costuming and Halloween, this was pretty much an instant sell. Having fully completed the game, I can assure you it did not disappoint.Right from the get-go, Costume Quest shows efforts to include every possible player, as you can choose to play as either the boy (Reynold) or girl (Wren) of a pair of twins. Soon after the twin you didn't select is kidnapped by monsters for dressing like a delicious-looking candy corn, you meet up with other trick-or-treaters your age that match your level of imagination and your desire to get your sibling back.Costume Quest feels like an RPG stripped down to its essentials, with timing-centric, turn-based combat and set amounts of spawns in most areas. This, along with the enemies' leveling along with you, eliminates the need for experience grinding. Wiping out everything is still necessary for 100% completion and makes getting costume upgrades and some secrets easier, but you can get by if you stick to story-necessary encounters.The game itself feels a bit small, area-wise, but there are plenty of tasks in each section to keep your party busy and searching for hidden items and secret costumes. A great balance is struck between backtracking through each section and forward progression, so it rarely, if ever, feels like a slog.The variety of costumes is also nice, especially their in-combat forms. Due to the children's imaginations, whatever costume they're wearing transforms into a majestic, towering version of its mundane representation, all featuring beautiful animations and unique, often hilarious special attacks. As touched on before, combat is straightforward, with timed button presses coming into play on top of the base mechanics to lessen incoming damage and stack combos with your own attacks.All in all, Costume Quest is relatively short, super sweet, and great for any time of year. Just remember that a couple of achievements (for the game and for the Grubbins On Ice DLC) are time-associated, so be ready to fire the game back up when more seasonably appropriate. You could just wiggle your PC clock a bit, but that'd be lame.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												This game is short and simplistic. The RPG combat is kinda like Paper Mario, in that you do QTEs to deal more damage. However, you usually only have the option to do a basic attack until your special is charged up (always after 3 turns) or you have a special stamp equipped. There are about ten costumes in both the normal game and the DLC, and only about half of them are worth using in combat compared to the others.Outside of combat, there are four enviroments to explore and solve puzzles in using costume abilities. You can hit basically anyone and anything with your candy pail, which is amusing. The dialogue isn't laugh out loud funny, but I smiled from time to time.The game really shines graphically. The characters are cute, the environments are given a lot of detail, and the battles look amazing. It's all very colorful. Music is average, however.All in all, playing this game is like playing a cartoon from Cartoon Network long ago. Worth buying if it's on sale.

Posted: January 19, 2016
 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine Costume Quest is an adventure game developed by the wonderful people behind Stacking, Brutal Legend and Grim Fandango: Remastered. Double Fine Producitons once again hits the nail again with their cleverly designed and well thought out gameCostume Quest is an adventure game where you play a brother and sister who go out during Halloween to do trick or treating but they find out that there are monsters known as Grubbins who are stealing all the candy, you have to stop them!Across the game's worlds you have to go and knock doors to ask for candy. Sometimes you will get regular human beings who give you candy, sometimes its the nasty Grubbins which it will send you into an RPG button prompt combat system. The combat system is sort of fun but can get very repetitive and boringThis game, the same with Stacking, is meant for people unlike me who are known as completionists. Completionists will have a ball playing Costume Quest and leveling up. The game's graphics are really cute and well designed, the music is nothing special but it is good neverthelessCostume Quest is very repetitive. Expect to enter the boring combat system multiple times and doing the same thing which is trick or treating can get boring and repetitive too. The game's difficulty is good but the game experiences a huge difficulty spike at the end, so much so, that many people I know who have played the game cannot beat the boss battle. I had a hell of a job trying to defeat the boss battle, but the game forces you to level up by completing other side missions and entering more of the boring combat system, which for me, I don't like... the game is okay at first but it can be impossible to finish if you are not leveled up properlyCostume Quest also offers an additional story through a free DLC known as Grubbins on Ice, I tried playing the DLC story, but sadly, I just gave up when the offered the same things as the original game...Don't get me wrong, Costume Quest is a wonderful game to play, however, with the game's repetitiveness, boring combat system and huge difficulty spike can put some people off, but overall it is a nice RPG adventure game to play RECOMMENDED :)

Posted: December 25, 2014
												If you don't care about achievements this review doesn't really apply to you.The game is OK and has some good humor (especially the Creepy Treat card names), but in all honesty it's very simple and pretty short, making it for many people just an easy achievement mine/perfect game completion... that is it would be."Tisn't the Season" for Double Fine developers to do their jobs apparently.  Adding an achievement that is a pure gimmick like to "Play Costume Quest on Christmas" (which has a a description that in the first place is ambiguous to people in other countries that celebrate more on the 24th), and which siad gimmick achievement prevents people from 100%ing the game is a slap in the face.  Many people on Mac and Linux systems are discussing this today and on Community guides so this is not an isolated occurance.  An achievement that is ostensibly only available one day in a year being broken on that day is unacceptable.  There are also reports that this has been a bug since 2012 and still hasn't been fixed.The game is released for Mac, Linux, and PC, DF devs... you don't get to support them unequally and not get called on it.Having steam link to the "game's website" and get a "server not found" error is a nice touch too.  Par for the course it seems.  Only real option if you don't have Windows is to write DF at support@doublefine.com

Posted: December 26, 2015
												Costume Quest is a lovable adventure you will never forget and if you do forget it, you are dead to me. This game is a superb JRPG with great level designs which sometimes want you to get a walkthrough (I had to use a walkthrough about 3-4 times). The story is a bit short but if you did all side quests (like me), you would at least have about 6-7 hours put in this. If you didnt do all side quests, you would have approximately 2-4 hours put in this. The game is beautiful for a halloween-themed game. Coffins are chests, you can trick-or-treat houses for candy or enemy encounters, battle stamps which improve your character in fights and several comedic speeches for all ages. I absolutely adore this game. Just like in every RPG game, there is a leveling up system. In order to level up, you defeat enemies (just like every RPG). It does take quite a while to level up in this game but that made me want to farm enemies and destroy bosses. Every game (excluding racing games) contain bosses (I think). These bosses were rather time consuming but if you had the right costumes for your team, it would be a piece of cake. I did find one boss in the game rather annoying but dont want to spoil it. I would say something about the boss, but just wait till you fight her. There are costumes you find from side quests or just main quests. These costumes play a big part of the game not just because its the games title, but you actually get different move sets aswell. The costumes I found made the final boss a 1 try victory for me. The game can be a bit easy if you get guides on where the costumes are located and its pieces. There is another playable DLC you get automatically if you purchase this game on steam, called Grubbins on Ice. It's not extremely long, its about 1/3 of the games length. I did enjoy it though because it gave me three costumes, several battle stamps and a nice adventure. I would prefer playing this after the base game because everthing from your first save in Costume Quest, gets sent over into the DLC. It's pretty helpful. It is recommended to do that because enemies are about lvl 13 and your cap is lvl 10 (in the base game). This game is a master piece literally. I love it so much and for the price I got it for (99 cents in the 2015 holiday sale) it was worth it. If you see this game going for about $5 or less, purchase it immediately. THIS TITLE IS A MUST-BUY. I LOVE YOU DOUBLE FINE PRODUCTIONS!

Posted: December 30, 2015
												Not badStoryYou are a kid that goes Trick and Treating with their sibling who is swiftly kidnapped by monsters. Now it is your job to go door to door trick or treating, complete quests, and fight monsters. It’s pretty much a standard RPG with a halloween theme painted on it. The story isn’t bad and it follows Double Fine’s formula well (kid looking game with often adult adventures that is eccentric). There are some dark elements to the game which come out really well and the whole game has a theme of child wonder to it. You fight as real transformers, unicorns, and vampires while facing daemons. It sounds like a kid fantasy. However, the story isn’t flushed out as Psychonauts for example and I don't really remember muchGameplayIt’s a standard RPG (with a twist). The main point is to go around to all of the stores/houses and trick or treat. Different areas are blocked out until you can unlock certain areas. This is mostly done through monster fights. Overall, this system is nice as it moves the plot along via your actions but gets very repetitive near the end as you just end up going from monster fight to monster fight. Speaking of which, the monster battles are a bit simple. You can have up to 3 characters each of which has a regular move and a special ability with a long cool down. Additionally, you have different patches you can apply which are absolutely necessary to stand a chance. It took me a while to find a pair that worked for me but in the end, it was all just the same thing over and over until the end. Overall, I found the system a bit simple and I don’t play RPGs muchPerformance:With a 4790k, GTX 970, and 16GB of ram, it ran at either 30 or 60fps for me. It didn’t vary in between those two numbers but rather certain scenes and areas were stuck at 30. The game isn’t aiming to be realistic so the graphics are cartoony.Overall, the game was OK. I’m reminded of South Park: The Stick of Truth a lot and honestly, I would recommend playing that over this game. It’s not bad but just kinda meh to above meh.
