Posted: May 7, 2015
												Costume Quest is a game about capitalism and the futility of fighting the system. You play as Wren or Reynold, fraternal twins locked into a system in which happiness is always kept at arm's length. Your twin, the object of your worldly fulfillment, is taken from you, and you are forced to incorporate yourself into the capitalist consumer machine in order to free them from bondage - i.e. willfully enslaving yourself even deeper in order to cast off perceived oppression. The erstwhile heroes are indoctrinated into consumerism through perceived need. Costumes and battle stamps are tools by which they can defeat their perceived oppressors, and candy and creepy treats are the currency by which they can obtain them. The creepy treats only award a special costume upon completing a full set, forcing the consumer-hero to seek out other members of their in-group to trade with and developing a reliance upon victimizing the out-group in order to obtain more. The same is true for candy, but on a much larger scale: widescale destruction and abuse of natural resources is encouraged, and upon reentering a zone the supply magically replenishes itself. Candy is ultimately spent on battle stamps, an entirely extraneous commodity that the game can be won without, but is marketed as invaluable and a means by which to constantly sink the children's personal supply of wealth.The true capitalist hero of this story is Sadie, a brave young entrepeneur with a monopoly on the battle stamps market who is happy to aid the heroes in their fight against the villainous 'monsters.' She allows her customers to develop a dependence upon her product before beginning to dramatically ramp up the price to obtain newer and better versions of the same - designed obselescence at its finest. By the end of the game the player is lucky if they have several hundred pieces of candy in their bucket, while Sadie sits on thousands that the player spent to constantly upgrade their battle stamps. The 'monsters' of the game are cast as villains bent on hoarding all the world's candy for themselves, when in reality they are collecting it in order to save their own lives. Sadie, on the other hand, is motivated purely by profit - lying, expanding, and price-gouging to drive it ever higher.The harsh reality is that this game is designed to indoctrinate the player into heedlessly reaping the world's resources and victimizing their competition in the name of achieving fulfillment. They are taught to at the same time fear and trust the two heads of the capitalist serpent, sybomically mirrored by the twin heads of the Doublefine logo: the Repugians, who are the face of foreign investments, and Sadie, the friendly face who is always there to help. 10/10 illuminati confirmed.

												Costume Quest did a great job of scratching my Final Fantasy itch without requiring the hundreds of hours your average FF game requires. The combat can be a bit repetitive, and the skill level is defnitely geared toward more novice players, but the game is short enough neither of these stuck around long enough to bother me. As one would expect from Double Fine, the art direction is fantastic, and the Creepy Treats cards are a great blend of Garbage Pail Kids-style art and trading cards with some of the best puns and just weird candies you can imagine. As a short treat or break from the norm, Costume Quest is sure to satisfy.

Posted: February 17, 2016
												This game is brilliantly nostalgic, combining engaging mechanics with the essence of Halloweens of yesteryear - before sugarphobia, when a bit of duct tape and cardboard could fire a kids' imagination, when All Hallows Eve was a time of innocent play and kids above a certain age were temporarily allowed out of the sight of their parents (who, in that ancient time, lacked the built-in helicopter blades which today eviscerate children's marrow). Relive the magic of days gone by with this game - or, if you are too young to remember that glorious era, discover what you missed.

Posted: March 16, 2016
												It's Halloween.  You're out trick or treating, and your brother/sister gets kidnapped!  It turns out that there is a plot by real monsters to steal all the candy in the world, and only you and your friends can stop them.Your costumes have different abilities to use while you're walking around town.  One has a flashlight so you can cross dark areas.  One has a helmet so you can cross areas with dripping water or debris.  One lets you roller skate and jump off ramps.  Another lets you into a secret club in your neighborhood.The costumes become REAL during combat, and each has a different fighting style.  So if you're dressed as the Statue of Liberty, you can use a healing spell to restore HP to the whole group, or you can hit the enemy with your torch to set them on fire.  If you are the robot, you can rocket-punch a single enemy or use your missiles to attack all the enemies.  And the other costumes have additional things going for them.  As you play more of the game, you will find parts of new costumes.  Only if you find all the parts can you make the costume.  In addition to changing costumes, you can also buy badges that give additional abilities.  One lets you add a little poison to your attacks.  Another adds a bigger poison with splash damage to nearby enemies.  Another boosts your HP so you live longer.  Another boosts your damage, but only if you make a critical hit.  You make a critical hit by getting good timing when you push the button displayed on screen.  Critical hits are very easy, I think I only ever missed two.  The first was because I didn't know how to do it yet, the second was because I sneezed and it messed up my timing.This game is not particularly difficult.  It is also not very big or long.  Still, it is fun for a little while.  It also has an expansion pack (standalone) where the kids visit the monster world at Christmas time and help the monsters overthrow a dictator.  New costumes are available in the expansion.  You can load your end-game save from the original game and start with the same characters, badges, and costumes when you boot up the expansion.Bottom line:  it's cute and fun, but don't expect too much from this one.

												Another great Double Fine game.  Short but still deilvers with the characters, story and gameplay. Just the feeling of beating monsters with my unicorn Costume is just down right fun.  Now I just wish that I can be in the Costume Quest universe a bit longer.

Posted: June 25, 2016
												I was brought up in American suburbia, and Halloween was always my favorite holiday growing up, probably because I was kind of a dork. I just loved the idea of one night where all kids, regardless of their popularity or class, got to assume fun new identities, put on cool costumes, go to their neighbors, and ask for candy. It was magical. I never liked the scarier parts of the holiday because I was always kind of a timid kid, but the dressing-up, the friendship that you could feel on Halloween night, was very special.With that said, this game is great. It's a love letter to suburban Halloween, with none of the scares and all of the fun and fantasy. I was a little skeptical of it before playing it as I had heard somewhat middling reviews upon its initial release, but after grabbing it in a Steam sale, I could not be happier with my purchase. Double Fine's characteristically thoughtful and funny writing is here in spades, and the characters you interact with are just delightful. That's a word I could apply to a lot of things in this game, actually—delightful.

Posted: June 26, 2016
												Costume Quest and it's sequel are colorful rpgs, with the usual mechanics. Press - here and such. However, they also have a sense of humor (And as always humor is subjective) The games are generally fun to play, the writing is funny, but there are a few reundancies in the script, as well as some sloppy writing. But that will only bother you a little (Or not at all if you're not a person particularly attached to grammar, and spelling. (I didn't notice any spelling issues)) The designs of the costumes, and of the in-fight character designs are pretty cool, though out of battle the costumes' design is more cute than anything else. The control scheme is a little difficult compared to console versions, but not so much so that it ruins the game. (Unless you have bad arthritis, than get a controller.)I got these games for a two for one sale for a dollar ninety-nine. Frankly, I think that this is terrible. These games aren't bargain bin garbage, they truly are worth playing.Mechanics: Pretty much the usual, costumes offer new methods of traversal. -+Graphics: Cartoony, but generally this improves the game. +Story: Written with humor, and generally enjoyable. Although, there were times where the script could've been refined, I quite enjoyed the story as a whole. +Gameplay: It was quite fun to play, maybe a little tedious if you can't find all of the houses, but this didn't bother me. + (That said this is the second game I ever fully completed, more commonly phrased as one hundred percenting)Controls: A little difficult to use, compared to console versions, but this doesn't ruin the game. And you could always get a controller. -Miscellaneous: The game was cute. But not overly cutesy, so you would have to punch a bear to get your manhood back after playing it.

Posted: January 19
												I loved this! It took me way too long to get it to work and I was even thinking of getting a refund at one point but I'm so glad I didn't. It's a family friendly Stick of Truth kind of game and the style feels like a blend between a ps1 and nds game. You only need one hand and a keyboard to play it so it's definitely a casual game.  Also I loved the little Stacking easter egg. Stacking was the first Double Fine game I played but apparenly it came out after Costume Quest and they announced the main character in the GOI part of this game.  Anyway, you should disable that sticky keys pop up because some of the costumes require you to press shift repeatedly. If you don't the pop up will crash your game. Never tab out of the game or you will get the callstack error and your game will crash. Don't try to change the resolution either. If you're on Windows 10 run this in Win 95 compatibility mode so the combat cutscenes don't crash your game. The FPS is capped at 30 and you probably shouldn't try to mess with that either. If you're ok with all of that then you'll probably love the game.

Posted: January 18
												I really enjoyed this game. It was bright, fun, and full of hidden items and quests. The characters were great, and the writing was clever - I particularly liked the really accurate twin rivalry, and the depth the monsters and villains were given. The battles were my least favorite bit, though. While the stamps and costumes give the characters a range of powers and tactics, I'm not fond of the hit-one-of-four-random-keys timed events. But then again, I'm used to puzzle games, so to each their own.Overall, excellent game, and I definitely recommend it!
